House File 2428 - Introduced


                                 HOUSE FILE 

                                 HOUSE FILE 
                                 HOUSE FILE                                  HOUSE FILE                                  BY  COMMITTEE ON JUDICIARY

                                 (SUCCESSOR TO HSB 606)

 A BILL FOR

  1 An Act providing for the establishment of a statewide sobriety
  2    and drug monitoring program to be used for certain criminal
  3    offenders in participating jurisdictions, and providing a
  4    penalty.
  5 BE IT ENACTED BY THE GENERAL ASSEMBLY OF THE STATE OF IOWA:
    TLSB 6005HV (1) 86
    ns/nh

PAG LIN



  1  1    Section 1.  LEGISLATIVE FINDINGS == PURPOSE.
  1  2    1.  The general assembly finds that operating a motor vehicle
  1  3 in this state is a privilege, not a right. A person who wishes
  1  4 to enjoy the benefits of this privilege shall accept the
  1  5 corresponding responsibilities.
  1  6    2.  The general assembly declares that the purpose of this
  1  7 Act is to do all of the following:
  1  8    a.  Protect the public health and welfare by reducing the
  1  9 number of people on the highways of this state who operate a
  1 10 motor vehicle under the influence of alcohol or a controlled
  1 11 substance.
  1 12    b.  Protect the public health and welfare by reducing the
  1 13 number of repeat offenders who commit crimes in which the abuse
  1 14 of alcohol or a controlled substance is a contributing factor
  1 15 in the commission of the crime.
  1 16    c.  Strengthen the pretrial and post=trial options available
  1 17 to prosecutors and judges in responding to repeat offenders who
  1 18 commit crimes in which the abuse of alcohol or a controlled
  1 19 substance is a contributing factor in the commission of the
  1 20 crime.
  1 21    d.  Assure the timely and sober participation of offenders
  1 22 in judicial proceedings.
  1 23    3.  The general assembly declares that it is important to
  1 24 have a centralized repository for all information related to
  1 25 alcohol and controlled substance testing required by the laws
  1 26 of this state or as a condition of bond, sentence, probation,
  1 27 parole, or a work permit.
  1 28    Sec. 2.  Section 321J.4, subsections 2 and 4, Code 2016, are
  1 29 amended to read as follows:
  1 30    2.  If a defendant is convicted of a violation of section
  1 31 321J.2, and the defendant's driver's license or nonresident
  1 32 operating privilege has not already been revoked under section
  1 33 321J.9 or 321J.12 for the occurrence from which the arrest
  1 34 arose, the department shall revoke the defendant's driver's
  1 35 license or nonresident operating privilege for one year if the
  2  1 defendant submitted to chemical testing and has had a previous
  2  2 conviction or revocation under this chapter and shall revoke
  2  3 the defendant's driver's license or nonresident operating
  2  4 privilege for two years if the defendant refused to submit to
  2  5 chemical testing and has had a previous revocation under this
  2  6 chapter. The defendant shall not be eligible for any temporary
  2  7 restricted license for forty=five days after the effective date
  2  8 of revocation if the defendant submitted to chemical testing
  2  9 and shall not be eligible for any temporary restricted license
  2 10 for ninety days after the effective date of revocation if the
  2 11 defendant refused chemical testing.  The temporary restricted
  2 12 license shall be issued in accordance with section 321J.20,
  2 13 subsection 2. The department shall require the defendant to
  2 14 install an ignition interlock device of a type approved by
  2 15 the commissioner of public safety on all vehicles owned or
  2 16 operated by the defendant
                                 (SUCCESSOR TO HSB 606)

 A BILL FOR

  1 An Act providing for the establishment of a statewide sobriety
  2    and drug monitoring program to be used for certain criminal
  3    offenders in participating jurisdictions, and providing a
  4    penalty.
  5 BE IT ENACTED BY THE GENERAL ASSEMBLY OF THE STATE OF IOWA:
    TLSB 6005HV (1) 86

  1 11 substance.

  1 13 number of repeat offenders who commit crimes in which the abuse
  1 14 of alcohol or a controlled substance is a contributing factor
  1 15 in the commission of the crime.
  1 16    c.  Strengthen the pretrial and post=trial options available
  1 17 to prosecutors and judges in responding to repeat offenders who
  1 18 commit crimes in which the abuse of alcohol or a controlled

  1 25 alcohol and controlled substance testing required by the laws
  1 26 of this state or as a condition of bond, sentence, probation,
  1 27 parole, or a work permit.
  1 28    Sec. 2.  Section 321J.4, subsections 2 and 4, Code 2016, are
  1 29 amended to read as follows:
  1 30    2.  If a defendant is convicted of a violation of section
  1 31 321J.2, and the defendant's driver's license or nonresident
  1 32 operating privilege has not already been revoked under section
  1 33 321J.9 or 321J.12 for the occurrence from which the arrest
  1 34 arose, the department shall revoke the defendant's driver's
  1 35 license or nonresident operating privilege for one year if the
  2  1 defendant submitted to chemical testing and has had a previous
  2  2 conviction or revocation under this chapter and shall revoke
  2  3 the defendant's driver's license or nonresident operating
  2  4 privilege for two years if the defendant refused to submit to
  2  5 chemical testing and has had a previous revocation under this
  2  6 chapter. The defendant shall not be eligible for any temporary
  2  7 restricted license for forty=five days after the effective date

  2  9 and shall not be eligible for any temporary restricted license
  2 10 for ninety days after the effective date of revocation if the
  2 11 defendant refused chemical testing.  The temporary restricted
  2 12 license shall be issued in accordance with section 321J.20,
  2 13 subsection 2. The department shall require the defendant to
  2 14 install an ignition interlock device of a type approved by
  2 15 the commissioner of public safety on all vehicles owned or
  2 16 operated by the defendant                                 (SUCCESSOR TO HSB 606)

  1 11 substance.
  1 12    b.  Protect the public health and welfare by reducing the
  1 13 number of repeat offenders who commit crimes in which the abuse
  1 14 of alcohol or a controlled substance is a contributing factor
  1 15 in the commission of the crime.
  1 16    c.  Strengthen the pretrial and post=trial options available
  1 17 to prosecutors and judges in responding to repeat offenders who
  1 18 commit crimes in which the abuse of alcohol or a controlled

  1 22 in judicial proceedings.

  1 26 of this state or as a condition of bond, sentence, probation,

  1 29 amended to read as follows:

  1 31 321J.2, and the defendant's driver's license or nonresident
  1 32 operating privilege has not already been revoked under section
  1 33 321J.9 or 321J.12 for the occurrence from which the arrest
  1 34 arose, the department shall revoke the defendant's driver's
  1 35 license or nonresident operating privilege for one year if the
  2  1 defendant submitted to chemical testing and has had a previous

  2 13 subsection 2. The department shall require the defendant to
  2 14 install an ignition interlock device of a type approved by
  2 15 the commissioner of public safety on all vehicles owned or
  2 16 operated by the defendant

  1 31 321J.2, and the defendant's driver's license or nonresident

  1 33 321J.9 or 321J.12 for the occurrence from which the arrest

  1 35 license or nonresident operating privilege for one year if the

  2  7 restricted license for forty=five days after the effective date
  2  8 of revocation if the defendant submitted to chemical testing
  2  9 and shall not be eligible for any temporary restricted license
  2 10 for ninety days after the effective date of revocation if the
  2 11 defendant refused chemical testing.  The temporary restricted
  2 12 license shall be issued in accordance with section 321J.20,
  2 13 subsection 2. The department shall require the defendant to
  2 14 install an ignition interlock device of a type approved by
  2 15 the commissioner of public safety on all vehicles owned or
  2 16 operated by the defendant  4    penalty.
  5 BE IT ENACTED BY THE GENERAL ASSEMBLY OF THE STATE OF IOWA:
    TLSB 6005HV (1) 86
    ns/nh

PAG LIN



  1  1    Section 1.  LEGISLATIVE FINDINGS == PURPOSE.
  1  2    1.  The general assembly finds that operating a motor vehicle
  1  3 in this state is a privilege, not a right. A person who wishes
  1  4 to enjoy the benefits of this privilege shall accept the
  1  5 corresponding responsibilities.
  1  6    2.  The general assembly declares that the purpose of this
  1  7 Act is to do all of the following:
  1  8    a.  Protect the public health and welfare by reducing the
  1  9 number of people on the highways of this state who operate a
  1 10 motor vehicle under the influence of alcohol or a controlled
  1 11 substance.
  1 12    b.  Protect the public health and welfare by reducing the
  1 13 number of repeat offenders who commit crimes in which the abuse
  1 14 of alcohol or a controlled substance is a contributing factor
  1 15 in the commission of the crime.
  1 16    c.  Strengthen the pretrial and post=trial options available
  1 17 to prosecutors and judges in responding to repeat offenders who
  1 18 commit crimes in which the abuse of alcohol or a controlled
  1 19 substance is a contributing factor in the commission of the
  1 20 crime.
  1 21    d.  Assure the timely and sober participation of offenders
  1 22 in judicial proceedings.
  1 23    3.  The general assembly declares that it is important to
  1 24 have a centralized repository for all information related to
  1 25 alcohol and controlled substance testing required by the laws
  1 26 of this state or as a condition of bond, sentence, probation,
  1 27 parole, or a work permit.
  1 28    Sec. 2.  Section 321J.4, subsections 2 and 4, Code 2016, are
  1 29 amended to read as follows:
  1 30    2.  If a defendant is convicted of a violation of section
  1 31 321J.2, and the defendant's driver's license or nonresident
  1 32 operating privilege has not already been revoked under section
  1 33 321J.9 or 321J.12 for the occurrence from which the arrest
  1 34 arose, the department shall revoke the defendant's driver's
  1 35 license or nonresident operating privilege for one year if the
  2  1 defendant submitted to chemical testing and has had a previous
  2  2 conviction or revocation under this chapter and shall revoke
  2  3 the defendant's driver's license or nonresident operating
  2  4 privilege for two years if the defendant refused to submit to
  2  5 chemical testing and has had a previous revocation under this
  2  6 chapter. The defendant shall not be eligible for any temporary
  2  7 restricted license for forty=five days after the effective date
  2  8 of revocation if the defendant submitted to chemical testing
  2  9 and shall not be eligible for any temporary restricted license
  2 10 for ninety days after the effective date of revocation if the
  2 11 defendant refused chemical testing.  The temporary restricted
  2 12 license shall be issued in accordance with section 321J.20,
  2 13 subsection 2. The department shall require the defendant to
  2 14 install an ignition interlock device of a type approved by
  2 15 the commissioner of public safety on all vehicles owned or
  2 16 operated by the defendant  5 BE IT ENACTED BY THE GENERAL ASSEMBLY OF THE STATE OF IOWA:
    TLSB 6005HV (1) 86
    ns/nh

PAG LIN



  1  1    Section 1.  LEGISLATIVE FINDINGS == PURPOSE.
  1  2    1.  The general assembly finds that operating a motor vehicle
  1  3 in this state is a privilege, not a right. A person who wishes
  1  4 to enjoy the benefits of this privilege shall accept the
  1  5 corresponding responsibilities.
  1  6    2.  The general assembly declares that the purpose of this
  1  7 Act is to do all of the following:
  1  8    a.  Protect the public health and welfare by reducing the
  1  9 number of people on the highways of this state who operate a
  1 10 motor vehicle under the influence of alcohol or a controlled
  1 11 substance.
  1 12    b.  Protect the public health and welfare by reducing the
  1 13 number of repeat offenders who commit crimes in which the abuse
  1 14 of alcohol or a controlled substance is a contributing factor
  1 15 in the commission of the crime.
  1 16    c.  Strengthen the pretrial and post=trial options available
  1 17 to prosecutors and judges in responding to repeat offenders who
  1 18 commit crimes in which the abuse of alcohol or a controlled
  1 19 substance is a contributing factor in the commission of the
  1 20 crime.
  1 21    d.  Assure the timely and sober participation of offenders
  1 22 in judicial proceedings.
  1 23    3.  The general assembly declares that it is important to
  1 24 have a centralized repository for all information related to
  1 25 alcohol and controlled substance testing required by the laws
  1 26 of this state or as a condition of bond, sentence, probation,
  1 27 parole, or a work permit.
  1 28    Sec. 2.  Section 321J.4, subsections 2 and 4, Code 2016, are
  1 29 amended to read as follows:
  1 30    2.  If a defendant is convicted of a violation of section
  1 31 321J.2, and the defendant's driver's license or nonresident
  1 32 operating privilege has not already been revoked under section
  1 33 321J.9 or 321J.12 for the occurrence from which the arrest
  1 34 arose, the department shall revoke the defendant's driver's
  1 35 license or nonresident operating privilege for one year if the
  2  1 defendant submitted to chemical testing and has had a previous
  2  2 conviction or revocation under this chapter and shall revoke
  2  3 the defendant's driver's license or nonresident operating
  2  4 privilege for two years if the defendant refused to submit to
  2  5 chemical testing and has had a previous revocation under this
  2  6 chapter. The defendant shall not be eligible for any temporary
  2  7 restricted license for forty=five days after the effective date
  2  8 of revocation if the defendant submitted to chemical testing
  2  9 and shall not be eligible for any temporary restricted license
  2 10 for ninety days after the effective date of revocation if the
  2 11 defendant refused chemical testing.  The temporary restricted
  2 12 license shall be issued in accordance with section 321J.20,
  2 13 subsection 2. The department shall require the defendant to
  2 14 install an ignition interlock device of a type approved by
  2 15 the commissioner of public safety on all vehicles owned or
  2 16 operated by the defendant

  1  1    Section 1.  LEGISLATIVE FINDINGS == PURPOSE.
  1  2    1.  The general assembly finds that operating a motor vehicle
  1  3 in this state is a privilege, not a right. A person who wishes
  1  4 to enjoy the benefits of this privilege shall accept the
  1  5 corresponding responsibilities.
  1  6    2.  The general assembly declares that the purpose of this
  1  7 Act is to do all of the following:
  1  8    a.  Protect the public health and welfare by reducing the
  1  9 number of people on the highways of this state who operate a
  1 10 motor vehicle under the influence of alcohol or a controlled
  1 11 substance.
  1 12    b.  Protect the public health and welfare by reducing the
  1 13 number of repeat offenders who commit crimes in which the abuse
  1 14 of alcohol or a controlled substance is a contributing factor
  1 15 in the commission of the crime.
  1 16    c.  Strengthen the pretrial and post=trial options available
  1 17 to prosecutors and judges in responding to repeat offenders who
  1 18 commit crimes in which the abuse of alcohol or a controlled
  1 19 substance is a contributing factor in the commission of the
  1 20 crime.
  1 21    d.  Assure the timely and sober participation of offenders
  1 22 in judicial proceedings.
  1 23    3.  The general assembly declares that it is important to
  1 24 have a centralized repository for all information related to
  1 25 alcohol and controlled substance testing required by the laws
  1 26 of this state or as a condition of bond, sentence, probation,
  1 27 parole, or a work permit.
  1 28    Sec. 2.  Section 321J.4, subsections 2 and 4, Code 2016, are
  1 29 amended to read as follows:
  1 30    2.  If a defendant is convicted of a violation of section
  1 31 321J.2, and the defendant's driver's license or nonresident
  1 32 operating privilege has not already been revoked under section
  1 33 321J.9 or 321J.12 for the occurrence from which the arrest
  1 34 arose, the department shall revoke the defendant's driver's
  1 35 license or nonresident operating privilege for one year if the
  2  1 defendant submitted to chemical testing and has had a previous
  2  2 conviction or revocation under this chapter and shall revoke
  2  3 the defendant's driver's license or nonresident operating
  2  4 privilege for two years if the defendant refused to submit to
  2  5 chemical testing and has had a previous revocation under this
  2  6 chapter. The defendant shall not be eligible for any temporary
  2  7 restricted license for forty=five days after the effective date
  2  8 of revocation if the defendant submitted to chemical testing
  2  9 and shall not be eligible for any temporary restricted license
  2 10 for ninety days after the effective date of revocation if the
  2 11 defendant refused chemical testing.  The temporary restricted
  2 12 license shall be issued in accordance with section 321J.20,
  2 13 subsection 2. The department shall require the defendant to
  2 14 install an ignition interlock device of a type approved by
  2 15 the commissioner of public safety on all vehicles owned or
  2 16 operated by the defendant

  2  8 of revocation if the defendant submitted to chemical testing
  2  9 and shall not be eligible for any temporary restricted license
  2 10 for ninety days after the effective date of revocation if the
  2 11 defendant refused chemical testing.  The temporary restricted
  2 12 license shall be issued in accordance with section 321J.20,
  2 13 subsection 2. The department shall require the defendant to
  2 14 install an ignition interlock device of a type approved by
  2 15 the commissioner of public safety on all vehicles owned or
  2 16 operated by the defendant  1  5 corresponding responsibilities.
  1  6    2.  The general assembly declares that the purpose of this
  1  7 Act is to do all of the following:
  1  8    a.  Protect the public health and welfare by reducing the
  1  9 number of people on the highways of this state who operate a
  1 10 motor vehicle under the influence of alcohol or a controlled
  1 11 substance.
  1 12    b.  Protect the public health and welfare by reducing the
  1 13 number of repeat offenders who commit crimes in which the abuse
  1 14 of alcohol or a controlled substance is a contributing factor
  1 15 in the commission of the crime.
  1 16    c.  Strengthen the pretrial and post=trial options available
  1 17 to prosecutors and judges in responding to repeat offenders who
  1 18 commit crimes in which the abuse of alcohol or a controlled
  1 19 substance is a contributing factor in the commission of the
  1 20 crime.
  1 21    d.  Assure the timely and sober participation of offenders
  1 22 in judicial proceedings.
  1 23    3.  The general assembly declares that it is important to
  1 24 have a centralized repository for all information related to
  1 25 alcohol and controlled substance testing required by the laws
  1 26 of this state or as a condition of bond, sentence, probation,
  1 27 parole, or a work permit.
  1 28    Sec. 2.  Section 321J.4, subsections 2 and 4, Code 2016, are
  1 29 amended to read as follows:
  1 30    2.  If a defendant is convicted of a violation of section
  1 31 321J.2, and the defendant's driver's license or nonresident
  1 32 operating privilege has not already been revoked under section
  1 33 321J.9 or 321J.12 for the occurrence from which the arrest
  1 34 arose, the department shall revoke the defendant's driver's
  1 35 license or nonresident operating privilege for one year if the
  2  1 defendant submitted to chemical testing and has had a previous
  2  2 conviction or revocation under this chapter and shall revoke
  2  3 the defendant's driver's license or nonresident operating
  2  4 privilege for two years if the defendant refused to submit to
  2  5 chemical testing and has had a previous revocation under this
  2  6 chapter. The defendant shall not be eligible for any temporary
  2  7 restricted license for forty=five days after the effective date

  1 31 321J.2, and the defendant's driver's license or nonresident
  1 32 operating privilege has not already been revoked under section
  1 33 321J.9 or 321J.12 for the occurrence from which the arrest
  1 34 arose, the department shall revoke the defendant's driver's
  1 35 license or nonresident operating privilege for one year if the
  2  1 defendant submitted to chemical testing and has had a previous
  2  2 conviction or revocation under this chapter and shall revoke
  2  3 the defendant's driver's license or nonresident operating
  2  4 privilege for two years if the defendant refused to submit to
  2  5 chemical testing and has had a previous revocation under this
  2  6 chapter. The defendant shall not be eligible for any temporary
  2  7 restricted license for forty=five days after the effective date
  2  8 of revocation if the defendant submitted to chemical testing
  2  9 and shall not be eligible for any temporary restricted license
  2 10 for ninety days after the effective date of revocation if the
  2 11 defendant refused chemical testing.  The temporary restricted
  2 12 license shall be issued in accordance with section 321J.20,
  2 13 subsection 2. The department shall require the defendant to
  2 14 install an ignition interlock device of a type approved by
  2 15 the commissioner of public safety on all vehicles owned or
  2 16 operated by the defendant  1 18 commit crimes in which the abuse of alcohol or a controlled
  1 19 substance is a contributing factor in the commission of the
  1 20 crime.
  1 21    d.  Assure the timely and sober participation of offenders
  1 22 in judicial proceedings.
  1 23    3.  The general assembly declares that it is important to
  1 24 have a centralized repository for all information related to
  1 25 alcohol and controlled substance testing required by the laws
  1 26 of this state or as a condition of bond, sentence, probation,
  1 27 parole, or a work permit.

  6 18    Sec. 8.    6 17 underlying revocation period for a violation of section 321J.2.
  6 18    Sec. 8.    6 18    Sec. 8.    6 19    This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the "Iowa
  6 20 Sobriety and Drug Monitoring Program Act".
  6 21    Sec. 9.    6 20 Sobriety and Drug Monitoring Program Act".
  6 21    Sec. 9.    6 21    Sec. 9.    6 22    As used in this chapter, unless the context otherwise
  6 23 requires:
  6 24    1.  "Alcohol" means an alcoholic beverage as defined in
  6 25 section 321J.1.
  6 26    2.  "Controlled substance" means as defined in section
  6 27 124.101.
  6 28    3.  "Department" means the department of public safety.
  6 29    4.  "Immediate sanction" means a sanction that is applied
  6 30 within minutes of a failed test result.
  6 31    5.  "Law enforcement agency" means a law enforcement agency
  6 32 charged with enforcement of the program created under this
  6 33 chapter.
  6 34    6.  "Participating jurisdiction" means a county or other
  6 35 governmental entity that chooses to participate in the program
  7  1 created under this chapter.
  7  2    7.  "Sobriety and drug monitoring program" or "program" means
  7  3 the program established pursuant to section 901D.3.
  7  4    8.  "Testing" means a procedure or set of procedures
  7  5 performed to determine the presence of alcohol or a controlled
  7  6 substance in a person's breath or bodily fluid, including
  7  7 blood, urine, saliva, and perspiration, and includes any
  7  8 combination of breath testing, drug patch testing, urine
  7  9 analysis testing, saliva testing, and continuous or transdermal
  7 10 alcohol monitoring. Subject to section 901D.3, the department
  7 11 may approve additional testing methodologies or the testing of
  7 12 alternative bodily fluids.
  7 13    9.  "Timely sanction" means a sanction that is applied within
  7 14 hours or days after a failed test result. A timely sanction
  7 15 shall be applied as soon as possible, but the period between
  7 16 the failed test result and the application of the timely
  7 17 sanction shall not exceed five days.
  7 18    Sec. 10.    6 23 requires:
  6 24    1.  "Alcohol" means an alcoholic beverage as defined in
  6 25 section 321J.1.
  6 26    2.  "Controlled substance" means as defined in section
  6 27 124.101.
  6 28    3.  "Department" means the department of public safety.
  6 29    4.  "Immediate sanction" means a sanction that is applied
  6 30 within minutes of a failed test result.

  6 32 charged with enforcement of the program created under this
  6 33 chapter.
  6 34    6.  "Participating jurisdiction" means a county or other
  6 35 governmental entity that chooses to participate in the program
  7  1 created under this chapter.
  7  2    7.  "Sobriety and drug monitoring program" or "program" means
  7  3 the program established pursuant to section 901D.3.
  7  4    8.  "Testing" means a procedure or set of procedures
  7  5 performed to determine the presence of alcohol or a controlled
  7  6 substance in a person's breath or bodily fluid, including

  7  8 combination of breath testing, drug patch testing, urine
  7  9 analysis testing, saliva testing, and continuous or transdermal
  7 10 alcohol monitoring. Subject to section 901D.3, the department
  7 11 may approve additional testing methodologies or the testing of
  7 12 alternative bodily fluids.
  7 13    9.  "Timely sanction" means a sanction that is applied within
  7 14 hours or days after a failed test result. A timely sanction
  7 15 shall be applied as soon as possible, but the period between
  7 16 the failed test result and the application of the timely
  7 17 sanction shall not exceed five days.

  7 13    9.  "Timely sanction" means a sanction that is applied within
  7 14 hours or days after a failed test result. A timely sanction
  7 15 shall be applied as soon as possible, but the period between
  7 16 the failed test result and the application of the timely
  7 17 sanction shall not exceed five days.
  7 18    Sec. 10.    7  5 performed to determine the presence of alcohol or a controlled
  7  6 substance in a person's breath or bodily fluid, including
  7  7 blood, urine, saliva, and perspiration, and includes any
  7  8 combination of breath testing, drug patch testing, urine
  7  9 analysis testing, saliva testing, and continuous or transdermal
  7 10 alcohol monitoring. Subject to section 901D.3, the department
  7 11 may approve additional testing methodologies or the testing of
  7 12 alternative bodily fluids.
  7 13    9.  "Timely sanction" means a sanction that is applied within
  7 14 hours or days after a failed test result. A timely sanction
  7 15 shall be applied as soon as possible, but the period between
  7 16 the failed test result and the application of the timely
  7 17 sanction shall not exceed five days.
  7 18    Sec. 10.    7  6 substance in a person's breath or bodily fluid, including
  7  7 blood, urine, saliva, and perspiration, and includes any
  7  8 combination of breath testing, drug patch testing, urine
  7  9 analysis testing, saliva testing, and continuous or transdermal
  7 10 alcohol monitoring. Subject to section 901D.3, the department
  7 11 may approve additional testing methodologies or the testing of
  7 12 alternative bodily fluids.
  7 13    9.  "Timely sanction" means a sanction that is applied within
  7 14 hours or days after a failed test result. A timely sanction
  7 15 shall be applied as soon as possible, but the period between
  7 16 the failed test result and the application of the timely
  7 17 sanction shall not exceed five days.
  7 18    Sec. 10.    7  7 blood, urine, saliva, and perspiration, and includes any
  7  8 combination of breath testing, drug patch testing, urine
  7  9 analysis testing, saliva testing, and continuous or transdermal
  7 10 alcohol monitoring. Subject to section 901D.3, the department
  7 11 may approve additional testing methodologies or the testing of
  7 12 alternative bodily fluids.

  7 14 hours or days after a failed test result. A timely sanction
  7 15 shall be applied as soon as possible, but the period between
  7 16 the failed test result and the application of the timely
  7 17 sanction shall not exceed five days.

  7  9 analysis testing, saliva testing, and continuous or transdermal
  7 10 alcohol monitoring. Subject to section 901D.3, the department
  7 11 may approve additional testing methodologies or the testing of
  7 12 alternative bodily fluids.

  7 14 hours or days after a failed test result. A timely sanction
  7 15 shall be applied as soon as possible, but the period between
  7 16 the failed test result and the application of the timely
  7 17 sanction shall not exceed five days.

  7 10 alcohol monitoring. Subject to section 901D.3, the department
  7 11 may approve additional testing methodologies or the testing of
  7 12 alternative bodily fluids.

  7 14 hours or days after a failed test result. A timely sanction
  7 15 shall be applied as soon as possible, but the period between
  7 16 the failed test result and the application of the timely
  7 17 sanction shall not exceed five days.
  7 18    Sec. 10.    7 10 alcohol monitoring. Subject to section 901D.3, the department
  7 11 may approve additional testing methodologies or the testing of
  7 12 alternative bodily fluids.
  7 13    9.  "Timely sanction" means a sanction that is applied within
  7 14 hours or days after a failed test result. A timely sanction
  7 15 shall be applied as soon as possible, but the period between
  7 16 the failed test result and the application of the timely
  7 17 sanction shall not exceed five days.
  7 18    Sec. 10.    7 11 may approve additional testing methodologies or the testing of
  7 12 alternative bodily fluids.
  7 13    9.  "Timely sanction" means a sanction that is applied within
  7 14 hours or days after a failed test result. A timely sanction
  7 15 shall be applied as soon as possible, but the period between
  7 16 the failed test result and the application of the timely
  7 17 sanction shall not exceed five days.
  7 18    Sec. 10.    7 12 alternative bodily fluids.
  7 13    9.  "Timely sanction" means a sanction that is applied within
  7 14 hours or days after a failed test result. A timely sanction
  7 15 shall be applied as soon as possible, but the period between
  7 16 the failed test result and the application of the timely
  7 17 sanction shall not exceed five days.
  7 18    Sec. 10.    7 13    9.  "Timely sanction" means a sanction that is applied within
  7 14 hours or days after a failed test result. A timely sanction
  7 15 shall be applied as soon as possible, but the period between
  7 16 the failed test result and the application of the timely
  7 17 sanction shall not exceed five days.
  7 18    Sec. 10.    7 14 hours or days after a failed test result. A timely sanction
  7 15 shall be applied as soon as possible, but the period between
  7 16 the failed test result and the application of the timely
  7 17 sanction shall not exceed five days.
  7 18    Sec. 10.    7 15 shall be applied as soon as possible, but the period between
  7 16 the failed test result and the application of the timely
  7 17 sanction shall not exceed five days.
  7 18    Sec. 10.    7 16 the failed test result and the application of the timely
  7 17 sanction shall not exceed five days.
  7 18    Sec. 10.    7 17 sanction shall not exceed five days.
  7 18    Sec. 10.    7 18    Sec. 10.    7 19    1.  The department of public safety shall establish a
  7 20 statewide sobriety and drug monitoring program to be used
  7 21 by participating jurisdictions, which shall be available
  7 22 twenty=four hours per day, seven days per week. Pursuant to
  7 23 the provisions of this chapter, a court or governmental entity,
  7 24 or an authorized officer thereof, within a participating
  7 25 jurisdiction may, as a condition of bond, sentence, probation,
  7 26 parole, or a work permit, do all of the following:
  7 27    a.  Require a person who has been charged with, pled guilty
  7 28 to, or been convicted of a crime in which the abuse of alcohol
  7 29 or a controlled substance was a contributing factor in the
  7 30 commission of the crime, including but not limited to a
  7 31 second or subsequent offense of operating while intoxicated in
  7 32 violation of section 321J.2 or 321J.2A, to abstain from alcohol
  7 33 and controlled substances for a period of time.
  7 34    b.  Require the person to be subject to testing to determine
  7 35 whether alcohol or a controlled substance is present in the
  8  1 person's body in the following manner:
  8  2    (1)  At least twice per day at a central location where an
  8  3 immediate sanction can be effectively applied.
  8  4    (2)  Where testing under subparagraph (1) creates a
  8  5 documented hardship or is geographically impractical, by an
  8  6 alternative method approved by the department and consistent
  8  7 with this section where a timely sanction can be effectively
  8  8 applied.
  8  9    2.  The program shall be evidence=based and shall satisfy at
  8 10 least two of the following requirements:
  8 11    a.  The program is included in the United States substance
  8 12 abuse and mental health services administration's national
  8 13 registry of evidence=based programs and practices.
  8 14    b.  The program has been reported in a peer=reviewed journal
  8 15 as having positive effects on the primary targeted outcome.
  8 16    c.  The program has been documented as effective by informed
  8 17 experts and other sources.
  8 18    3.  a.  The core components of the program shall include
  8 19 the use of a primary testing methodology for determining the
  8 20 presence of alcohol or a controlled substance in a person that
  8 21 best facilitates the ability of a law enforcement agency to
  8 22 apply immediate sanctions for failed test results and that is
  8 23 available at an affordable cost.
  8 24    b.  In cases of documented hardship or geographic
  8 25 impracticality, or in cases where a program participant
  8 26 has received less stringent testing requirements, testing
  8 27 methodologies that best facilitate the ability of a law
  8 28 enforcement agency to apply timely sanctions for noncompliant
  8 29 test results may be utilized. For purposes of this section,
  8 30 hardship or geographic impracticality shall be determined by
  8 31 documentation and consideration of the following factors:
  8 32    (1)  Whether a testing device is available.
  8 33    (2)  Whether the participant is capable of paying the fees
  8 34 and costs associated with the testing device.
  8 35    (3)  Whether the participant is capable of wearing the
  9  1 testing device.
  9  2    (4)  Whether the participant fails to qualify for testing
  9  3 twice per day because of one or more of the following:
  9  4    (a)  The participant lives in a rural area and submitting to
  9  5 testing twice per day would be unduly burdensome.
  9  6    (b)  The participant's employment requires the participant's
  9  7 presence at a location remote from the testing location and
  9  8 submitting to testing twice per day would be unduly burdensome.
  9  9    (c)  The participant has repeatedly violated the
  9 10 requirements of the program while submitting to testing twice
  9 11 per day and poses a substantial risk of continuing to violate
  9 12 the requirements of the program.
  9 13    4.  If a jurisdiction chooses to participate in the program,
  9 14 the department shall assist the jurisdiction in setting up and
  9 15 administering the program in that jurisdiction in compliance
  9 16 with this chapter.
  9 17    5.  a.  If a jurisdiction participates in the program, the
  9 18 participating jurisdiction or a law enforcement agency of the
  9 19 participating jurisdiction may designate a third party to
  9 20 provide testing services or to take any other action required
  9 21 or authorized to be provided by the participating jurisdiction
  9 22 or law enforcement agency under this chapter, except a
  9 23 third=party designee shall not determine whether to participate
  9 24 in the program.
  9 25    b.  The participating jurisdiction, in consultation with the
  9 26 law enforcement agency of the participating jurisdiction, shall
  9 27 establish testing locations for the program.
  9 28    6.  Any efforts by the department to alter or modify a core
  9 29 component of the program shall include a documented strategy
  9 30 for achieving and measuring the effectiveness of the planned
  9 31 alteration or modification. Before the department alters or
  9 32 modifies a core component of the program, a pilot program
  9 33 with defined objectives and timelines shall be initiated, and
  9 34 measurements of the effectiveness and impact of the proposed
  9 35 alteration or modification to a core component shall be
 10  1 monitored. The data shall be assessed and the department
 10  2 shall make a determination as to whether the stated goals of
 10  3 the alteration or modification were achieved and whether the
 10  4 alteration or modification should be formally implemented into
 10  5 the program.
 10  6    Sec. 11.    7 20 statewide sobriety and drug monitoring program to be used
  7 21 by participating jurisdictions, which shall be available

  9 23 third=party designee shall not determine whether to participate
  9 24 in the program.
  9 25    b.  The participating jurisdiction, in consultation with the
  9 26 law enforcement agency of the participating jurisdiction, shall
  9 27 establish testing locations for the program.
  9 28    6.  Any efforts by the department to alter or modify a core
  9 29 component of the program shall include a documented strategy
  9 30 for achieving and measuring the effectiveness of the planned
  9 31 alteration or modification. Before the department alters or
  9 32 modifies a core component of the program, a pilot program
  9 33 with defined objectives and timelines shall be initiated, and
  9 34 measurements of the effectiveness and impact of the proposed
  9 35 alteration or modification to a core component shall be
 10  1 monitored. The data shall be assessed and the department
 10  2 shall make a determination as to whether the stated goals of
 10  3 the alteration or modification were achieved and whether the
 10  4 alteration or modification should be formally implemented into
 10  5 the program.

  9  7 presence at a location remote from the testing location and
  9  8 submitting to testing twice per day would be unduly burdensome.
  9  9    (c)  The participant has repeatedly violated the
  9 10 requirements of the program while submitting to testing twice
  9 11 per day and poses a substantial risk of continuing to violate
  9 12 the requirements of the program.
  9 13    4.  If a jurisdiction chooses to participate in the program,
  9 14 the department shall assist the jurisdiction in setting up and
  9 15 administering the program in that jurisdiction in compliance
  9 16 with this chapter.
  9 17    5.  a.  If a jurisdiction participates in the program, the
  9 18 participating jurisdiction or a law enforcement agency of the
  9 19 participating jurisdiction may designate a third party to
  9 20 provide testing services or to take any other action required
  9 21 or authorized to be provided by the participating jurisdiction
  9 22 or law enforcement agency under this chapter, except a
  9 23 third=party designee shall not determine whether to participate
  9 24 in the program.
  9 25    b.  The participating jurisdiction, in consultation with the
  9 26 law enforcement agency of the participating jurisdiction, shall
  9 27 establish testing locations for the program.
  9 28    6.  Any efforts by the department to alter or modify a core
  9 29 component of the program shall include a documented strategy
  9 30 for achieving and measuring the effectiveness of the planned
  9 31 alteration or modification. Before the department alters or
  9 32 modifies a core component of the program, a pilot program
  9 33 with defined objectives and timelines shall be initiated, and
  9 34 measurements of the effectiveness and impact of the proposed
  9 35 alteration or modification to a core component shall be
 10  1 monitored. The data shall be assessed and the department
 10  2 shall make a determination as to whether the stated goals of
 10  3 the alteration or modification were achieved and whether the
 10  4 alteration or modification should be formally implemented into
 10  5 the program.
 10  6    Sec. 11.    7 24 or an authorized officer thereof, within a participating
  7 25 jurisdiction may, as a condition of bond, sentence, probation,
  7 26 parole, or a work permit, do all of the following:
  7 27    a.  Require a person who has been charged with, pled guilty
  7 28 to, or been convicted of a crime in which the abuse of alcohol
  7 29 or a controlled substance was a contributing factor in the
  7 30 commission of the crime, including but not limited to a
  7 31 second or subsequent offense of operating while intoxicated in
  7 32 violation of section 321J.2 or 321J.2A, to abstain from alcohol
  7 33 and controlled substances for a period of time.
  7 34    b.  Require the person to be subject to testing to determine
  7 35 whether alcohol or a controlled substance is present in the
  8  1 person's body in the following manner:
  8  2    (1)  At least twice per day at a central location where an
  8  3 immediate sanction can be effectively applied.
  8  4    (2)  Where testing under subparagraph (1) creates a
  8  5 documented hardship or is geographically impractical, by an
  8  6 alternative method approved by the department and consistent
  8  7 with this section where a timely sanction can be effectively
  8  8 applied.
  8  9    2.  The program shall be evidence=based and shall satisfy at
  8 10 least two of the following requirements:
  8 11    a.  The program is included in the United States substance
  8 12 abuse and mental health services administration's national
  8 13 registry of evidence=based programs and practices.
  8 14    b.  The program has been reported in a peer=reviewed journal
  8 15 as having positive effects on the primary targeted outcome.
  8 16    c.  The program has been documented as effective by informed
  8 17 experts and other sources.
  8 18    3.  a.  The core components of the program shall include
  8 19 the use of a primary testing methodology for determining the
  8 20 presence of alcohol or a controlled substance in a person that
  8 21 best facilitates the ability of a law enforcement agency to
  8 22 apply immediate sanctions for failed test results and that is
  8 23 available at an affordable cost.
  8 24    b.  In cases of documented hardship or geographic
  8 25 impracticality, or in cases where a program participant
  8 26 has received less stringent testing requirements, testing
  8 27 methodologies that best facilitate the ability of a law
  8 28 enforcement agency to apply timely sanctions for noncompliant
  8 29 test results may be utilized. For purposes of this section,
  8 30 hardship or geographic impracticality shall be determined by
  8 31 documentation and consideration of the following factors:
  8 32    (1)  Whether a testing device is available.
  8 33    (2)  Whether the participant is capable of paying the fees
  8 34 and costs associated with the testing device.
  8 35    (3)  Whether the participant is capable of wearing the
  9  1 testing device.
  9  2    (4)  Whether the participant fails to qualify for testing
  9  3 twice per day because of one or more of the following:
  9  4    (a)  The participant lives in a rural area and submitting to
  9  5 testing twice per day would be unduly burdensome.
  9  6    (b)  The participant's employment requires the participant's
  9  7 presence at a location remote from the testing location and
  9  8 submitting to testing twice per day would be unduly burdensome.
  9  9    (c)  The participant has repeatedly violated the
  9 10 requirements of the program while submitting to testing twice
  9 11 per day and poses a substantial risk of continuing to violate
  9 12 the requirements of the program.
  9 13    4.  If a jurisdiction chooses to participate in the program,
  9 14 the department shall assist the jurisdiction in setting up and
  9 15 administering the program in that jurisdiction in compliance
  9 16 with this chapter.
  9 17    5.  a.  If a jurisdiction participates in the program, the
  9 18 participating jurisdiction or a law enforcement agency of the
  9 19 participating jurisdiction may designate a third party to
  9 20 provide testing services or to take any other action required
  9 21 or authorized to be provided by the participating jurisdiction
  9 22 or law enforcement agency under this chapter, except a
  9 23 third=party designee shall not determine whether to participate
  9 24 in the program.
  9 25    b.  The participating jurisdiction, in consultation with the
  9 26 law enforcement agency of the participating jurisdiction, shall
  9 27 establish testing locations for the program.
  9 28    6.  Any efforts by the department to alter or modify a core
  9 29 component of the program shall include a documented strategy
  9 30 for achieving and measuring the effectiveness of the planned
  9 31 alteration or modification. Before the department alters or
  9 32 modifies a core component of the program, a pilot program
  9 33 with defined objectives and timelines shall be initiated, and
  9 34 measurements of the effectiveness and impact of the proposed
  9 35 alteration or modification to a core component shall be
 10  1 monitored. The data shall be assessed and the department
 10  2 shall make a determination as to whether the stated goals of
 10  3 the alteration or modification were achieved and whether the
 10  4 alteration or modification should be formally implemented into
 10  5 the program.

  9 26 law enforcement agency of the participating jurisdiction, shall
  9 27 establish testing locations for the program.
  9 28    6.  Any efforts by the department to alter or modify a core
  9 29 component of the program shall include a documented strategy
  9 30 for achieving and measuring the effectiveness of the planned
  9 31 alteration or modification. Before the department alters or
  9 32 modifies a core component of the program, a pilot program
  9 33 with defined objectives and timelines shall be initiated, and
  9 34 measurements of the effectiveness and impact of the proposed
  9 35 alteration or modification to a core component shall be
 10  1 monitored. The data shall be assessed and the department
 10  2 shall make a determination as to whether the stated goals of
 10  3 the alteration or modification were achieved and whether the
 10  4 alteration or modification should be formally implemented into
 10  5 the program.
 10  6    Sec. 11.    7 30 commission of the crime, including but not limited to a
  7 31 second or subsequent offense of operating while intoxicated in
  7 32 violation of section 321J.2 or 321J.2A, to abstain from alcohol
  7 33 and controlled substances for a period of time.
  7 34    b.  Require the person to be subject to testing to determine
  7 35 whether alcohol or a controlled substance is present in the
  8  1 person's body in the following manner:
  8  2    (1)  At least twice per day at a central location where an
  8  3 immediate sanction can be effectively applied.
  8  4    (2)  Where testing under subparagraph (1) creates a
  8  5 documented hardship or is geographically impractical, by an
  8  6 alternative method approved by the department and consistent
  8  7 with this section where a timely sanction can be effectively
  8  8 applied.
  8  9    2.  The program shall be evidence=based and shall satisfy at
  8 10 least two of the following requirements:
  8 11    a.  The program is included in the United States substance
  8 12 abuse and mental health services administration's national
  8 13 registry of evidence=based programs and practices.
  8 14    b.  The program has been reported in a peer=reviewed journal
  8 15 as having positive effects on the primary targeted outcome.
  8 16    c.  The program has been documented as effective by informed
  8 17 experts and other sources.
  8 18    3.  a.  The core components of the program shall include
  8 19 the use of a primary testing methodology for determining the
  8 20 presence of alcohol or a controlled substance in a person that
  8 21 best facilitates the ability of a law enforcement agency to
  8 22 apply immediate sanctions for failed test results and that is
  8 23 available at an affordable cost.
  8 24    b.  In cases of documented hardship or geographic
  8 25 impracticality, or in cases where a program participant
  8 26 has received less stringent testing requirements, testing
  8 27 methodologies that best facilitate the ability of a law
  8 28 enforcement agency to apply timely sanctions for noncompliant
  8 29 test results may be utilized. For purposes of this section,
  8 30 hardship or geographic impracticality shall be determined by
  8 31 documentation and consideration of the following factors:
  8 32    (1)  Whether a testing device is available.
  8 33    (2)  Whether the participant is capable of paying the fees
  8 34 and costs associated with the testing device.
  8 35    (3)  Whether the participant is capable of wearing the
  9  1 testing device.
  9  2    (4)  Whether the participant fails to qualify for testing
  9  3 twice per day because of one or more of the following:
  9  4    (a)  The participant lives in a rural area and submitting to
  9  5 testing twice per day would be unduly burdensome.
  9  6    (b)  The participant's employment requires the participant's
  9  7 presence at a location remote from the testing location and
  9  8 submitting to testing twice per day would be unduly burdensome.
  9  9    (c)  The participant has repeatedly violated the
  9 10 requirements of the program while submitting to testing twice
  9 11 per day and poses a substantial risk of continuing to violate
  9 12 the requirements of the program.
  9 13    4.  If a jurisdiction chooses to participate in the program,
  9 14 the department shall assist the jurisdiction in setting up and
  9 15 administering the program in that jurisdiction in compliance
  9 16 with this chapter.
  9 17    5.  a.  If a jurisdiction participates in the program, the
  9 18 participating jurisdiction or a law enforcement agency of the
  9 19 participating jurisdiction may designate a third party to
  9 20 provide testing services or to take any other action required
  9 21 or authorized to be provided by the participating jurisdiction
  9 22 or law enforcement agency under this chapter, except a
  9 23 third=party designee shall not determine whether to participate
  9 24 in the program.
  9 25    b.  The participating jurisdiction, in consultation with the
  9 26 law enforcement agency of the participating jurisdiction, shall
  9 27 establish testing locations for the program.
  9 28    6.  Any efforts by the department to alter or modify a core
  9 29 component of the program shall include a documented strategy
  9 30 for achieving and measuring the effectiveness of the planned
  9 31 alteration or modification. Before the department alters or
  9 32 modifies a core component of the program, a pilot program
  9 33 with defined objectives and timelines shall be initiated, and
  9 34 measurements of the effectiveness and impact of the proposed
  9 35 alteration or modification to a core component shall be
 10  1 monitored. The data shall be assessed and the department
 10  2 shall make a determination as to whether the stated goals of
 10  3 the alteration or modification were achieved and whether the
 10  4 alteration or modification should be formally implemented into
 10  5 the program.

  9  9    (c)  The participant has repeatedly violated the
  9 10 requirements of the program while submitting to testing twice
  9 11 per day and poses a substantial risk of continuing to violate
  9 12 the requirements of the program.
  9 13    4.  If a jurisdiction chooses to participate in the program,
  9 14 the department shall assist the jurisdiction in setting up and
  9 15 administering the program in that jurisdiction in compliance
  9 16 with this chapter.
  9 17    5.  a.  If a jurisdiction participates in the program, the
  9 18 participating jurisdiction or a law enforcement agency of the
  9 19 participating jurisdiction may designate a third party to
  9 20 provide testing services or to take any other action required
  9 21 or authorized to be provided by the participating jurisdiction
  9 22 or law enforcement agency under this chapter, except a
  9 23 third=party designee shall not determine whether to participate
  9 24 in the program.
  9 25    b.  The participating jurisdiction, in consultation with the
  9 26 law enforcement agency of the participating jurisdiction, shall
  9 27 establish testing locations for the program.
  9 28    6.  Any efforts by the department to alter or modify a core
  9 29 component of the program shall include a documented strategy
  9 30 for achieving and measuring the effectiveness of the planned
  9 31 alteration or modification. Before the department alters or
  9 32 modifies a core component of the program, a pilot program
  9 33 with defined objectives and timelines shall be initiated, and
  9 34 measurements of the effectiveness and impact of the proposed
  9 35 alteration or modification to a core component shall be
 10  1 monitored. The data shall be assessed and the department
 10  2 shall make a determination as to whether the stated goals of
 10  3 the alteration or modification were achieved and whether the
 10  4 alteration or modification should be formally implemented into
 10  5 the program.
 10  6    Sec. 11.    8  2    (1)  At least twice per day at a central location where an
  8  3 immediate sanction can be effectively applied.
  8  4    (2)  Where testing under subparagraph (1) creates a
  8  5 documented hardship or is geographically impractical, by an
  8  6 alternative method approved by the department and consistent
  8  7 with this section where a timely sanction can be effectively
  8  8 applied.
  8  9    2.  The program shall be evidence=based and shall satisfy at
  8 10 least two of the following requirements:
  8 11    a.  The program is included in the United States substance
  8 12 abuse and mental health services administration's national
  8 13 registry of evidence=based programs and practices.
  8 14    b.  The program has been reported in a peer=reviewed journal
  8 15 as having positive effects on the primary targeted outcome.
  8 16    c.  The program has been documented as effective by informed
  8 17 experts and other sources.
  8 18    3.  a.  The core components of the program shall include
  8 19 the use of a primary testing methodology for determining the
  8 20 presence of alcohol or a controlled substance in a person that
  8 21 best facilitates the ability of a law enforcement agency to
  8 22 apply immediate sanctions for failed test results and that is
  8 23 available at an affordable cost.
  8 24    b.  In cases of documented hardship or geographic
  8 25 impracticality, or in cases where a program participant
  8 26 has received less stringent testing requirements, testing
  8 27 methodologies that best facilitate the ability of a law
  8 28 enforcement agency to apply timely sanctions for noncompliant
  8 29 test results may be utilized. For purposes of this section,
  8 30 hardship or geographic impracticality shall be determined by
  8 31 documentation and consideration of the following factors:
  8 32    (1)  Whether a testing device is available.
  8 33    (2)  Whether the participant is capable of paying the fees
  8 34 and costs associated with the testing device.
  8 35    (3)  Whether the participant is capable of wearing the
  9  1 testing device.
  9  2    (4)  Whether the participant fails to qualify for testing
  9  3 twice per day because of one or more of the following:
  9  4    (a)  The participant lives in a rural area and submitting to
  9  5 testing twice per day would be unduly burdensome.
  9  6    (b)  The participant's employment requires the participant's
  9  7 presence at a location remote from the testing location and
  9  8 submitting to testing twice per day would be unduly burdensome.
  9  9    (c)  The participant has repeatedly violated the
  9 10 requirements of the program while submitting to testing twice
  9 11 per day and poses a substantial risk of continuing to violate
  9 12 the requirements of the program.
  9 13    4.  If a jurisdiction chooses to participate in the program,
  9 14 the department shall assist the jurisdiction in setting up and
  9 15 administering the program in that jurisdiction in compliance
  9 16 with this chapter.
  9 17    5.  a.  If a jurisdiction participates in the program, the
  9 18 participating jurisdiction or a law enforcement agency of the
  9 19 participating jurisdiction may designate a third party to
  9 20 provide testing services or to take any other action required
  9 21 or authorized to be provided by the participating jurisdiction
  9 22 or law enforcement agency under this chapter, except a
  9 23 third=party designee shall not determine whether to participate
  9 24 in the program.
  9 25    b.  The participating jurisdiction, in consultation with the
  9 26 law enforcement agency of the participating jurisdiction, shall
  9 27 establish testing locations for the program.
  9 28    6.  Any efforts by the department to alter or modify a core
  9 29 component of the program shall include a documented strategy
  9 30 for achieving and measuring the effectiveness of the planned
  9 31 alteration or modification. Before the department alters or
  9 32 modifies a core component of the program, a pilot program
  9 33 with defined objectives and timelines shall be initiated, and
  9 34 measurements of the effectiveness and impact of the proposed
  9 35 alteration or modification to a core component shall be
 10  1 monitored. The data shall be assessed and the department
 10  2 shall make a determination as to whether the stated goals of
 10  3 the alteration or modification were achieved and whether the
 10  4 alteration or modification should be formally implemented into
 10  5 the program.

  8 15 as having positive effects on the primary targeted outcome.
  8 16    c.  The program has been documented as effective by informed
  8 17 experts and other sources.
  8 18    3.  a.  The core components of the program shall include
  8 19 the use of a primary testing methodology for determining the
  8 20 presence of alcohol or a controlled substance in a person that
  8 21 best facilitates the ability of a law enforcement agency to
  8 22 apply immediate sanctions for failed test results and that is
  8 23 available at an affordable cost.
  8 24    b.  In cases of documented hardship or geographic
  8 25 impracticality, or in cases where a program participant
  8 26 has received less stringent testing requirements, testing
  8 27 methodologies that best facilitate the ability of a law
  8 28 enforcement agency to apply timely sanctions for noncompliant
  8 29 test results may be utilized. For purposes of this section,
  8 30 hardship or geographic impracticality shall be determined by
  8 31 documentation and consideration of the following factors:
  8 32    (1)  Whether a testing device is available.
  8 33    (2)  Whether the participant is capable of paying the fees
  8 34 and costs associated with the testing device.
  8 35    (3)  Whether the participant is capable of wearing the
  9  1 testing device.
  9  2    (4)  Whether the participant fails to qualify for testing
  9  3 twice per day because of one or more of the following:
  9  4    (a)  The participant lives in a rural area and submitting to
  9  5 testing twice per day would be unduly burdensome.
  9  6    (b)  The participant's employment requires the participant's
  9  7 presence at a location remote from the testing location and
  9  8 submitting to testing twice per day would be unduly burdensome.
  9  9    (c)  The participant has repeatedly violated the
  9 10 requirements of the program while submitting to testing twice
  9 11 per day and poses a substantial risk of continuing to violate
  9 12 the requirements of the program.
  9 13    4.  If a jurisdiction chooses to participate in the program,
  9 14 the department shall assist the jurisdiction in setting up and
  9 15 administering the program in that jurisdiction in compliance
  9 16 with this chapter.
  9 17    5.  a.  If a jurisdiction participates in the program, the
  9 18 participating jurisdiction or a law enforcement agency of the
  9 19 participating jurisdiction may designate a third party to
  9 20 provide testing services or to take any other action required
  9 21 or authorized to be provided by the participating jurisdiction
  9 22 or law enforcement agency under this chapter, except a
  9 23 third=party designee shall not determine whether to participate
  9 24 in the program.
  9 25    b.  The participating jurisdiction, in consultation with the
  9 26 law enforcement agency of the participating jurisdiction, shall
  9 27 establish testing locations for the program.
  9 28    6.  Any efforts by the department to alter or modify a core
  9 29 component of the program shall include a documented strategy
  9 30 for achieving and measuring the effectiveness of the planned
  9 31 alteration or modification. Before the department alters or
  9 32 modifies a core component of the program, a pilot program
  9 33 with defined objectives and timelines shall be initiated, and
  9 34 measurements of the effectiveness and impact of the proposed
  9 35 alteration or modification to a core component shall be
 10  1 monitored. The data shall be assessed and the department
 10  2 shall make a determination as to whether the stated goals of
 10  3 the alteration or modification were achieved and whether the
 10  4 alteration or modification should be formally implemented into
 10  5 the program.
 10  6    Sec. 11.    8 10 least two of the following requirements:
  8 11    a.  The program is included in the United States substance
  8 12 abuse and mental health services administration's national
  8 13 registry of evidence=based programs and practices.
  8 14    b.  The program has been reported in a peer=reviewed journal
  8 15 as having positive effects on the primary targeted outcome.
  8 16    c.  The program has been documented as effective by informed
  8 17 experts and other sources.

  9 15 administering the program in that jurisdiction in compliance
  9 16 with this chapter.
  9 17    5.  a.  If a jurisdiction participates in the program, the
  9 18 participating jurisdiction or a law enforcement agency of the
  9 19 participating jurisdiction may designate a third party to
  9 20 provide testing services or to take any other action required
  9 21 or authorized to be provided by the participating jurisdiction
  9 22 or law enforcement agency under this chapter, except a
  9 23 third=party designee shall not determine whether to participate
  9 24 in the program.
  9 25    b.  The participating jurisdiction, in consultation with the
  9 26 law enforcement agency of the participating jurisdiction, shall
  9 27 establish testing locations for the program.
  9 28    6.  Any efforts by the department to alter or modify a core
  9 29 component of the program shall include a documented strategy
  9 30 for achieving and measuring the effectiveness of the planned
  9 31 alteration or modification. Before the department alters or
  9 32 modifies a core component of the program, a pilot program
  9 33 with defined objectives and timelines shall be initiated, and
  9 34 measurements of the effectiveness and impact of the proposed
  9 35 alteration or modification to a core component shall be
 10  1 monitored. The data shall be assessed and the department
 10  2 shall make a determination as to whether the stated goals of
 10  3 the alteration or modification were achieved and whether the
 10  4 alteration or modification should be formally implemented into
 10  5 the program.
 10  6    Sec. 11.    8 18    3.  a.  The core components of the program shall include
  8 19 the use of a primary testing methodology for determining the
  8 20 presence of alcohol or a controlled substance in a person that
  8 21 best facilitates the ability of a law enforcement agency to
  8 22 apply immediate sanctions for failed test results and that is
  8 23 available at an affordable cost.
  8 24    b.  In cases of documented hardship or geographic
  8 25 impracticality, or in cases where a program participant
  8 26 has received less stringent testing requirements, testing
  8 27 methodologies that best facilitate the ability of a law
  8 28 enforcement agency to apply timely sanctions for noncompliant
  8 29 test results may be utilized. For purposes of this section,
  8 30 hardship or geographic impracticality shall be determined by
  8 31 documentation and consideration of the following factors:
  8 32    (1)  Whether a testing device is available.
  8 33    (2)  Whether the participant is capable of paying the fees
  8 34 and costs associated with the testing device.
  8 35    (3)  Whether the participant is capable of wearing the
  9  1 testing device.
  9  2    (4)  Whether the participant fails to qualify for testing
  9  3 twice per day because of one or more of the following:
  9  4    (a)  The participant lives in a rural area and submitting to
  9  5 testing twice per day would be unduly burdensome.
  9  6    (b)  The participant's employment requires the participant's
  9  7 presence at a location remote from the testing location and
  9  8 submitting to testing twice per day would be unduly burdensome.
  9  9    (c)  The participant has repeatedly violated the
  9 10 requirements of the program while submitting to testing twice
  9 11 per day and poses a substantial risk of continuing to violate
  9 12 the requirements of the program.
  9 13    4.  If a jurisdiction chooses to participate in the program,
  9 14 the department shall assist the jurisdiction in setting up and
  9 15 administering the program in that jurisdiction in compliance
  9 16 with this chapter.
  9 17    5.  a.  If a jurisdiction participates in the program, the
  9 18 participating jurisdiction or a law enforcement agency of the
  9 19 participating jurisdiction may designate a third party to
  9 20 provide testing services or to take any other action required
  9 21 or authorized to be provided by the participating jurisdiction
  9 22 or law enforcement agency under this chapter, except a
  9 23 third=party designee shall not determine whether to participate
  9 24 in the program.
  9 25    b.  The participating jurisdiction, in consultation with the
  9 26 law enforcement agency of the participating jurisdiction, shall
  9 27 establish testing locations for the program.

  9 16 with this chapter.
  9 17    5.  a.  If a jurisdiction participates in the program, the
  9 18 participating jurisdiction or a law enforcement agency of the
  9 19 participating jurisdiction may designate a third party to
  9 20 provide testing services or to take any other action required
  9 21 or authorized to be provided by the participating jurisdiction
  9 22 or law enforcement agency under this chapter, except a
  9 23 third=party designee shall not determine whether to participate
  9 24 in the program.
  9 25    b.  The participating jurisdiction, in consultation with the
  9 26 law enforcement agency of the participating jurisdiction, shall
  9 27 establish testing locations for the program.
  9 28    6.  Any efforts by the department to alter or modify a core
  9 29 component of the program shall include a documented strategy
  9 30 for achieving and measuring the effectiveness of the planned
  9 31 alteration or modification. Before the department alters or
  9 32 modifies a core component of the program, a pilot program
  9 33 with defined objectives and timelines shall be initiated, and
  9 34 measurements of the effectiveness and impact of the proposed
  9 35 alteration or modification to a core component shall be
 10  1 monitored. The data shall be assessed and the department
 10  2 shall make a determination as to whether the stated goals of
 10  3 the alteration or modification were achieved and whether the
 10  4 alteration or modification should be formally implemented into
 10  5 the program.
 10  6    Sec. 11.    8 28 enforcement agency to apply timely sanctions for noncompliant
  8 29 test results may be utilized. For purposes of this section,
  8 30 hardship or geographic impracticality shall be determined by
  8 31 documentation and consideration of the following factors:
  8 32    (1)  Whether a testing device is available.
  8 33    (2)  Whether the participant is capable of paying the fees
  8 34 and costs associated with the testing device.
  8 35    (3)  Whether the participant is capable of wearing the
  9  1 testing device.
  9  2    (4)  Whether the participant fails to qualify for testing
  9  3 twice per day because of one or more of the following:
  9  4    (a)  The participant lives in a rural area and submitting to
  9  5 testing twice per day would be unduly burdensome.
  9  6    (b)  The participant's employment requires the participant's
  9  7 presence at a location remote from the testing location and
  9  8 submitting to testing twice per day would be unduly burdensome.
  9  9    (c)  The participant has repeatedly violated the
  9 10 requirements of the program while submitting to testing twice
  9 11 per day and poses a substantial risk of continuing to violate
  9 12 the requirements of the program.
  9 13    4.  If a jurisdiction chooses to participate in the program,
  9 14 the department shall assist the jurisdiction in setting up and
  9 15 administering the program in that jurisdiction in compliance
  9 16 with this chapter.
  9 17    5.  a.  If a jurisdiction participates in the program, the
  9 18 participating jurisdiction or a law enforcement agency of the
  9 19 participating jurisdiction may designate a third party to
  9 20 provide testing services or to take any other action required
  9 21 or authorized to be provided by the participating jurisdiction
  9 22 or law enforcement agency under this chapter, except a
  9 23 third=party designee shall not determine whether to participate
  9 24 in the program.
  9 25    b.  The participating jurisdiction, in consultation with the
  9 26 law enforcement agency of the participating jurisdiction, shall
  9 27 establish testing locations for the program.
  9 28    6.  Any efforts by the department to alter or modify a core
  9 29 component of the program shall include a documented strategy
  9 30 for achieving and measuring the effectiveness of the planned
  9 31 alteration or modification. Before the department alters or
  9 32 modifies a core component of the program, a pilot program
  9 33 with defined objectives and timelines shall be initiated, and
  9 34 measurements of the effectiveness and impact of the proposed
  9 35 alteration or modification to a core component shall be
 10  1 monitored. The data shall be assessed and the department
 10  2 shall make a determination as to whether the stated goals of
 10  3 the alteration or modification were achieved and whether the
 10  4 alteration or modification should be formally implemented into
 10  5 the program.

 10  5 the program.
 10  6    Sec. 11.    9  5 testing twice per day would be unduly burdensome.
  9  6    (b)  The participant's employment requires the participant's
  9  7 presence at a location remote from the testing location and
  9  8 submitting to testing twice per day would be unduly burdensome.
  9  9    (c)  The participant has repeatedly violated the
  9 10 requirements of the program while submitting to testing twice
  9 11 per day and poses a substantial risk of continuing to violate
  9 12 the requirements of the program.
  9 13    4.  If a jurisdiction chooses to participate in the program,
  9 14 the department shall assist the jurisdiction in setting up and
  9 15 administering the program in that jurisdiction in compliance
  9 16 with this chapter.
  9 17    5.  a.  If a jurisdiction participates in the program, the
  9 18 participating jurisdiction or a law enforcement agency of the
  9 19 participating jurisdiction may designate a third party to
  9 20 provide testing services or to take any other action required
  9 21 or authorized to be provided by the participating jurisdiction
  9 22 or law enforcement agency under this chapter, except a
  9 23 third=party designee shall not determine whether to participate
  9 24 in the program.
  9 25    b.  The participating jurisdiction, in consultation with the
  9 26 law enforcement agency of the participating jurisdiction, shall
  9 27 establish testing locations for the program.
  9 28    6.  Any efforts by the department to alter or modify a core
  9 29 component of the program shall include a documented strategy
  9 30 for achieving and measuring the effectiveness of the planned
  9 31 alteration or modification. Before the department alters or
  9 32 modifies a core component of the program, a pilot program
  9 33 with defined objectives and timelines shall be initiated, and
  9 34 measurements of the effectiveness and impact of the proposed
  9 35 alteration or modification to a core component shall be
 10  1 monitored. The data shall be assessed and the department
 10  2 shall make a determination as to whether the stated goals of
 10  3 the alteration or modification were achieved and whether the
 10  4 alteration or modification should be formally implemented into
 10  5 the program.
 10  6    Sec. 11.    9  6    (b)  The participant's employment requires the participant's
  9  7 presence at a location remote from the testing location and
  9  8 submitting to testing twice per day would be unduly burdensome.
  9  9    (c)  The participant has repeatedly violated the
  9 10 requirements of the program while submitting to testing twice
  9 11 per day and poses a substantial risk of continuing to violate
  9 12 the requirements of the program.

  9 31 alteration or modification. Before the department alters or
  9 32 modifies a core component of the program, a pilot program
  9 33 with defined objectives and timelines shall be initiated, and
  9 34 measurements of the effectiveness and impact of the proposed
  9 35 alteration or modification to a core component shall be
 10  1 monitored. The data shall be assessed and the department
 10  2 shall make a determination as to whether the stated goals of
 10  3 the alteration or modification were achieved and whether the
 10  4 alteration or modification should be formally implemented into
 10  5 the program.
 10  6    Sec. 11.    9 27 establish testing locations for the program.
  9 28    6.  Any efforts by the department to alter or modify a core
  9 29 component of the program shall include a documented strategy
  9 30 for achieving and measuring the effectiveness of the planned
  9 31 alteration or modification. Before the department alters or
  9 32 modifies a core component of the program, a pilot program
  9 33 with defined objectives and timelines shall be initiated, and
  9 34 measurements of the effectiveness and impact of the proposed
  9 35 alteration or modification to a core component shall be
 10  1 monitored. The data shall be assessed and the department
 10  2 shall make a determination as to whether the stated goals of
 10  3 the alteration or modification were achieved and whether the
 10  4 alteration or modification should be formally implemented into
 10  5 the program.
 10  6    Sec. 11.    9 28    6.  Any efforts by the department to alter or modify a core

 10  5 the program.

 10  6    Sec. 11.   10  5 the program.
 10  6    Sec. 11.   10  6    Sec. 11.   10  7    The department may adopt rules pursuant to chapter 17A to
 10  8 administer this chapter, including but not limited to rules
 10  9 regarding any of the following:
 10 10    1.  Providing for the nature and manner of testing, including
 10 11 the procedures and apparatus to be used for testing.
 10 12    2.  Establishing reasonable participant, enrollment, and
 10 13 testing fees for the program, including fees to pay the costs
 10 14 of installation, monitoring, and deactivation of any testing
 10 15 device. The fees shall be set at an amount such that the fees
 10 16 collected in a participating jurisdiction are sufficient to pay
 10 17 for the costs of the program in the participating jurisdiction,
 10 18 including all costs to the state associated with the program in
 10 19 the participating jurisdiction.
 10 20    3.  Providing for the application, acceptance, and use of
 10 21 public and private grants, gifts, and donations to support
 10 22 program activities.
 10 23    4.  Establishing a process for the identification and
 10 24 management of indigent participants.
 10 25    5.  Providing for the creation and administration of a
 10 26 stakeholder group to review and recommend changes to the
 10 27 program.
 10 28    Sec. 12.   10  8 administer this chapter, including but not limited to rules
 10  9 regarding any of the following:

 10 11 the procedures and apparatus to be used for testing.

 10 13 testing fees for the program, including fees to pay the costs
 10 14 of installation, monitoring, and deactivation of any testing
 10 15 device. The fees shall be set at an amount such that the fees
 10 16 collected in a participating jurisdiction are sufficient to pay
 10 17 for the costs of the program in the participating jurisdiction,
 10 18 including all costs to the state associated with the program in
 10 19 the participating jurisdiction.

 10 21 public and private grants, gifts, and donations to support
 10 22 program activities.
 10 23    4.  Establishing a process for the identification and
 10 24 management of indigent participants.
 10 25    5.  Providing for the creation and administration of a
 10 26 stakeholder group to review and recommend changes to the
 10 27 program.
