 10 28    Sec. 12.   10 27 program.
 10 28    Sec. 12.   10 28    Sec. 12.   10 29    1.  The department shall provide for and approve the use
 10 30 of a program data management system that shall be used by
 10 31 the department and all participating jurisdictions to manage
 10 32 testing, test events, test results, data access, fees, the
 10 33 collection of fee payments, and the submission and collection
 10 34 of any required reports.
 10 35    2.  The data management system shall include but is not
 11  1 limited to all of the following features:
 11  2    a.  A secure, remotely hosted, demonstrated, internet=based
 11  3 management application that allows multiple concurrent users to
 11  4 access and input information.
 11  5    b.  The support of breath testing, continuous remote
 11  6 transdermal alcohol monitoring, drug patch testing, and urine
 11  7 analysis testing.
 11  8    c.  The capability to track and store events including
 11  9 but not limited to participant enrollment, testing activity,
 11 10 accounting activity, and participating law enforcement agency
 11 11 activity.
 11 12    d.  The capability to generate reports of system fields and
 11 13 data. The data management system shall allow reports to be
 11 14 generated as needed and on a scheduled basis, and shall allow
 11 15 reports to be exported over a network connection or by remote
 11 16 printing.
 11 17    e.  The ability to identify program participants who have
 11 18 previously been enrolled in a similar program in this state or
 11 19 another state.
 11 20    3.  Unless otherwise required by federal law, all alcohol or
 11 21 controlled substance testing performed as a condition of bond,
 11 22 sentence, probation, parole, or a work permit shall utilize and
 11 23 input results to the data management system.
 11 24    4.  The data management system shall contain sufficient
 11 25 security protocols to protect participants' personal
 11 26 information from unauthorized use.
 11 27    Sec. 13.   10 30 of a program data management system that shall be used by
 10 31 the department and all participating jurisdictions to manage
 10 32 testing, test events, test results, data access, fees, the
 10 33 collection of fee payments, and the submission and collection
 10 34 of any required reports.

 11 21 controlled substance testing performed as a condition of bond,
 11 22 sentence, probation, parole, or a work permit shall utilize and
 11 23 input results to the data management system.
 11 24    4.  The data management system shall contain sufficient
 11 25 security protocols to protect participants' personal
 11 26 information from unauthorized use.
 11 27    Sec. 13.   11  2    a.  A secure, remotely hosted, demonstrated, internet=based
 11  3 management application that allows multiple concurrent users to
 11  4 access and input information.
 11  5    b.  The support of breath testing, continuous remote
 11  6 transdermal alcohol monitoring, drug patch testing, and urine
 11  7 analysis testing.
 11  8    c.  The capability to track and store events including
 11  9 but not limited to participant enrollment, testing activity,
 11 10 accounting activity, and participating law enforcement agency
 11 11 activity.
 11 12    d.  The capability to generate reports of system fields and
 11 13 data. The data management system shall allow reports to be
 11 14 generated as needed and on a scheduled basis, and shall allow
 11 15 reports to be exported over a network connection or by remote
 11 16 printing.
 11 17    e.  The ability to identify program participants who have
 11 18 previously been enrolled in a similar program in this state or
 11 19 another state.

 11 27    Sec. 13.   11 24    4.  The data management system shall contain sufficient
 11 25 security protocols to protect participants' personal
 11 26 information from unauthorized use.
 11 27    Sec. 13.   11 25 security protocols to protect participants' personal
 11 26 information from unauthorized use.
 11 27    Sec. 13.   11 26 information from unauthorized use.
 11 27    Sec. 13.   11 27    Sec. 13.   11 28 participation.
 11 29    1.  A court or governmental entity, or an authorized officer
 11 30 thereof, in a participating jurisdiction may utilize the
 11 31 program as provided in this section. The program shall be a
 11 32 preferred program for offenders charged with or convicted of a
 11 33 second or subsequent offense of operating while intoxicated in
 11 34 violation of section 321J.2 or 321J.2A, or a crime in which the
 11 35 abuse of alcohol or a controlled substance was a contributing
 12  1 factor in the commission of the crime.
 12  2    2.  If a person convicted of a second or subsequent offense
 12  3 of operating while intoxicated has been required to participate
 12  4 in the program, has financial liability coverage pursuant
 12  5 to section 321.20B, and the minimum period of ineligibility
 12  6 for issuance of a temporary restricted license has expired
 12  7 pursuant to chapter 321J, the court may notify the department
 12  8 of transportation that, as a participant in the program, the
 12  9 person is eligible for a temporary restricted license pursuant
 12 10 to section 321J.20.
 12 11    3.  A court may condition any bond or pretrial release
 12 12 otherwise authorized by law for a person charged with a second
 12 13 or subsequent offense of operating while intoxicated, or
 12 14 with any crime in which the abuse of alcohol or a controlled
 12 15 substance was a contributing factor in the commission of the
 12 16 crime, upon participation in the program and payment of the
 12 17 fees established pursuant to section 901D.4.
 12 18    4.  A court may condition the granting of a suspended
 12 19 sentence or probation otherwise authorized by law for a person
 12 20 convicted of a second or subsequent offense of operating
 12 21 while intoxicated, or any crime in which the abuse of alcohol
 12 22 or a controlled substance was a contributing factor in the
 12 23 commission of the crime, upon participation in the program and
 12 24 payment of the fees established pursuant to section 901D.4.
 12 25    5.  The board of parole, the department of corrections, or
 12 26 a parole officer may condition parole otherwise authorized by
 12 27 law for a person convicted of a second or subsequent offense of
 12 28 operating while intoxicated, or any crime in which the abuse of
 12 29 alcohol or a controlled substance was a contributing factor in
 12 30 the commission of the crime, upon participation in the program
 12 31 and payment of the fees established pursuant to section 901D.4.
 12 32    Sec. 14.   11 29    1.  A court or governmental entity, or an authorized officer
 11 30 thereof, in a participating jurisdiction may utilize the

 12 32    Sec. 14.   12 24 payment of the fees established pursuant to section 901D.4.
 12 25    5.  The board of parole, the department of corrections, or
 12 26 a parole officer may condition parole otherwise authorized by
 12 27 law for a person convicted of a second or subsequent offense of
 12 28 operating while intoxicated, or any crime in which the abuse of
 12 29 alcohol or a controlled substance was a contributing factor in
 12 30 the commission of the crime, upon participation in the program
 12 31 and payment of the fees established pursuant to section 901D.4.
 12 32    Sec. 14.   12 25    5.  The board of parole, the department of corrections, or
 12 26 a parole officer may condition parole otherwise authorized by
 12 27 law for a person convicted of a second or subsequent offense of
 12 28 operating while intoxicated, or any crime in which the abuse of
 12 29 alcohol or a controlled substance was a contributing factor in
 12 30 the commission of the crime, upon participation in the program
 12 31 and payment of the fees established pursuant to section 901D.4.

 12 28 operating while intoxicated, or any crime in which the abuse of
 12 29 alcohol or a controlled substance was a contributing factor in
 12 30 the commission of the crime, upon participation in the program
 12 31 and payment of the fees established pursuant to section 901D.4.

 12 31 and payment of the fees established pursuant to section 901D.4.
 12 32    Sec. 14.   12 31 and payment of the fees established pursuant to section 901D.4.
 12 32    Sec. 14.   12 32    Sec. 14.   12 33    1.  Subject to section 901D.6, a participant may be placed in
 12 34 the program as a condition of bond, pretrial release, sentence,
 12 35 probation, or parole.
 13  1    2.  An order or directive placing a participant in the
 13  2 program shall include the type of testing required to be
 13  3 administered in the program and the length of time that the
 13  4 participant is required to remain in the program. The person
 13  5 issuing the order or directive shall send a copy of the order
 13  6 or directive to the law enforcement agency of the participating
 13  7 jurisdiction.
 13  8    3.  Upon receipt of a copy of an order or directive,
 13  9 a representative of the law enforcement agency of the
 13 10 participating jurisdiction shall enroll a participant in the
 13 11 program prior to testing.
 13 12    4.  At the time of enrollment, a representative of the law
 13 13 enforcement agency of the participating jurisdiction shall
 13 14 enter the participant's information into the data management
 13 15 system described in section 901D.5. The representative of
 13 16 the agency shall provide the participant with the appropriate
 13 17 materials required by the program, inform the participant that
 13 18 the participant's information may be shared for law enforcement
 13 19 and reporting purposes, and provide the participant with
 13 20 information related to the required testing, procedures, and
 13 21 fees.
 13 22    5.  The participant shall sign a form stating that the
 13 23 participant understands the program requirements and releases
 13 24 the participant's information for law enforcement and reporting
 13 25 purposes.
 13 26    6.  A participant shall report to the program for testing for
 13 27 the length of time ordered by the court, the board of parole,
 13 28 the department of corrections, or a parole officer.

 13 29    Sec. 15.   13 28 the department of corrections, or a parole officer.
 13 29    Sec. 15.   13 29    Sec. 15.   13 30 use of fees.
 13 31    1.  The law enforcement agency of a participating
 13 32 jurisdiction shall do all of the following:
 13 33    a.  Establish and maintain a sobriety program account.
 13 34    b.  Collect the participant, enrollment, and testing fees
 13 35 established pursuant to section 901D.4 and deposit the fees
 14  1 and any other funds received for the program into the sobriety
 14  2 program account for administration of the program.
 14  3    2.  A participant shall pay all fees directly to the law
 14  4 enforcement agency of the participating jurisdiction.
 14  5    3.  a.  The law enforcement agency shall distribute a
 14  6 portion of the fees to any participating third=party designee
 14  7 in accordance with the agreement between the agency and the
 14  8 third=party designee.
 14  9    b.  The remainder of the fees collected shall be deposited in
 14 10 the sobriety program account, and shall be used only for the
 14 11 purposes of administering and operating the program.
 14 12    Sec. 16.   13 31    1.  The law enforcement agency of a participating
 13 32 jurisdiction shall do all of the following:
 13 33    a.  Establish and maintain a sobriety program account.
 13 34    b.  Collect the participant, enrollment, and testing fees
 13 35 established pursuant to section 901D.4 and deposit the fees
 14  1 and any other funds received for the program into the sobriety
 14  2 program account for administration of the program.
 14  3    2.  A participant shall pay all fees directly to the law
 14  4 enforcement agency of the participating jurisdiction.
 14  5    3.  a.  The law enforcement agency shall distribute a
 14  6 portion of the fees to any participating third=party designee
 14  7 in accordance with the agreement between the agency and the
 14  8 third=party designee.
 14  9    b.  The remainder of the fees collected shall be deposited in
 14 10 the sobriety program account, and shall be used only for the
 14 11 purposes of administering and operating the program.
 14 12    Sec. 16.   13 32 jurisdiction shall do all of the following:
 13 33    a.  Establish and maintain a sobriety program account.
 13 34    b.  Collect the participant, enrollment, and testing fees
 13 35 established pursuant to section 901D.4 and deposit the fees
 14  1 and any other funds received for the program into the sobriety
 14  2 program account for administration of the program.
 14  3    2.  A participant shall pay all fees directly to the law
 14  4 enforcement agency of the participating jurisdiction.
 14  5    3.  a.  The law enforcement agency shall distribute a
 14  6 portion of the fees to any participating third=party designee
 14  7 in accordance with the agreement between the agency and the
 14  8 third=party designee.
 14  9    b.  The remainder of the fees collected shall be deposited in
 14 10 the sobriety program account, and shall be used only for the
 14 11 purposes of administering and operating the program.
 14 12    Sec. 16.   13 33    a.  Establish and maintain a sobriety program account.
 13 34    b.  Collect the participant, enrollment, and testing fees
 13 35 established pursuant to section 901D.4 and deposit the fees
 14  1 and any other funds received for the program into the sobriety
 14  2 program account for administration of the program.
 14  3    2.  A participant shall pay all fees directly to the law
 14  4 enforcement agency of the participating jurisdiction.
 14  5    3.  a.  The law enforcement agency shall distribute a
 14  6 portion of the fees to any participating third=party designee
 14  7 in accordance with the agreement between the agency and the
 14  8 third=party designee.
 14  9    b.  The remainder of the fees collected shall be deposited in
 14 10 the sobriety program account, and shall be used only for the
 14 11 purposes of administering and operating the program.
 14 12    Sec. 16.   13 34    b.  Collect the participant, enrollment, and testing fees
 13 35 established pursuant to section 901D.4 and deposit the fees
 14  1 and any other funds received for the program into the sobriety
 14  2 program account for administration of the program.
 14  3    2.  A participant shall pay all fees directly to the law
 14  4 enforcement agency of the participating jurisdiction.
 14  5    3.  a.  The law enforcement agency shall distribute a
 14  6 portion of the fees to any participating third=party designee
 14  7 in accordance with the agreement between the agency and the
 14  8 third=party designee.
 14  9    b.  The remainder of the fees collected shall be deposited in
 14 10 the sobriety program account, and shall be used only for the
 14 11 purposes of administering and operating the program.
 14 12    Sec. 16.   13 35 established pursuant to section 901D.4 and deposit the fees
 14  1 and any other funds received for the program into the sobriety
 14  2 program account for administration of the program.
 14  3    2.  A participant shall pay all fees directly to the law
 14  4 enforcement agency of the participating jurisdiction.
 14  5    3.  a.  The law enforcement agency shall distribute a
 14  6 portion of the fees to any participating third=party designee
 14  7 in accordance with the agreement between the agency and the
 14  8 third=party designee.
 14  9    b.  The remainder of the fees collected shall be deposited in
 14 10 the sobriety program account, and shall be used only for the
 14 11 purposes of administering and operating the program.
 14 12    Sec. 16.   14  1 and any other funds received for the program into the sobriety
 14  2 program account for administration of the program.
 14  3    2.  A participant shall pay all fees directly to the law
 14  4 enforcement agency of the participating jurisdiction.
 14  5    3.  a.  The law enforcement agency shall distribute a
 14  6 portion of the fees to any participating third=party designee
 14  7 in accordance with the agreement between the agency and the
 14  8 third=party designee.
 14  9    b.  The remainder of the fees collected shall be deposited in
 14 10 the sobriety program account, and shall be used only for the
 14 11 purposes of administering and operating the program.
 14 12    Sec. 16.   14  2 program account for administration of the program.
 14  3    2.  A participant shall pay all fees directly to the law
 14  4 enforcement agency of the participating jurisdiction.
 14  5    3.  a.  The law enforcement agency shall distribute a
 14  6 portion of the fees to any participating third=party designee
 14  7 in accordance with the agreement between the agency and the
 14  8 third=party designee.
 14  9    b.  The remainder of the fees collected shall be deposited in
 14 10 the sobriety program account, and shall be used only for the
 14 11 purposes of administering and operating the program.
 14 12    Sec. 16.   14  3    2.  A participant shall pay all fees directly to the law
 14  4 enforcement agency of the participating jurisdiction.
 14  5    3.  a.  The law enforcement agency shall distribute a
 14  6 portion of the fees to any participating third=party designee
 14  7 in accordance with the agreement between the agency and the
 14  8 third=party designee.
 14  9    b.  The remainder of the fees collected shall be deposited in
 14 10 the sobriety program account, and shall be used only for the
 14 11 purposes of administering and operating the program.
 14 12    Sec. 16.   14  4 enforcement agency of the participating jurisdiction.
 14  5    3.  a.  The law enforcement agency shall distribute a
 14  6 portion of the fees to any participating third=party designee
 14  7 in accordance with the agreement between the agency and the
 14  8 third=party designee.
 14  9    b.  The remainder of the fees collected shall be deposited in
 14 10 the sobriety program account, and shall be used only for the
 14 11 purposes of administering and operating the program.
 14 12    Sec. 16.   14  5    3.  a.  The law enforcement agency shall distribute a
 14  6 portion of the fees to any participating third=party designee
 14  7 in accordance with the agreement between the agency and the
 14  8 third=party designee.
 14  9    b.  The remainder of the fees collected shall be deposited in
 14 10 the sobriety program account, and shall be used only for the
 14 11 purposes of administering and operating the program.
 14 12    Sec. 16.   14  6 portion of the fees to any participating third=party designee
 14  7 in accordance with the agreement between the agency and the
 14  8 third=party designee.
 14  9    b.  The remainder of the fees collected shall be deposited in
 14 10 the sobriety program account, and shall be used only for the
 14 11 purposes of administering and operating the program.
 14 12    Sec. 16.   14  7 in accordance with the agreement between the agency and the
 14  8 third=party designee.
 14  9    b.  The remainder of the fees collected shall be deposited in
 14 10 the sobriety program account, and shall be used only for the
 14 11 purposes of administering and operating the program.
 14 12    Sec. 16.   14  8 third=party designee.
 14  9    b.  The remainder of the fees collected shall be deposited in
 14 10 the sobriety program account, and shall be used only for the
 14 11 purposes of administering and operating the program.
 14 12    Sec. 16.   14  9    b.  The remainder of the fees collected shall be deposited in
 14 10 the sobriety program account, and shall be used only for the
 14 11 purposes of administering and operating the program.
 14 12    Sec. 16.   14 10 the sobriety program account, and shall be used only for the
 14 11 purposes of administering and operating the program.
 14 12    Sec. 16.   14 11 purposes of administering and operating the program.
 14 12    Sec. 16.   14 12    Sec. 16.   14 13    1.  Upon the failure of a participant to submit to or pass a
 14 14 test under the program, a peace officer, probation officer, or
 14 15 parole officer shall complete a written statement establishing
 14 16 that the participant, in the judgment of the officer, violated
 14 17 a condition of release or a condition of the program by failing
 14 18 to submit to or pass a test. A peace officer shall immediately
 14 19 arrest the person without a warrant after completing or
 14 20 receiving the written statement.
 14 21    2.  A person taken into custody pursuant to this section
 14 22 shall appear before a court within a reasonable amount of time
 14 23 and shall not be released unless the person has made a personal
 14 24 appearance before a court.
 14 25    3.  The court may notify the department of transportation
 14 26 of the person's noncompliance and direct the department
 14 27 to withdraw any temporary restricted license issued to the
 14 28 person and reinstate the remainder of any applicable license
 14 29 suspension or revocation period provided by chapter 321J.
 14 30                           EXPLANATION
 14 31 The inclusion of this explanation does not constitute agreement with
 14 32 the explanation's substance by the members of the general assembly.
 14 33    This bill directs the department of public safety (DPS) to
 14 34 establish a statewide sobriety and drug monitoring program that
 14 35 is available 24 hours per day, seven days per week. Under
 15  1 the program, a court or governmental entity, as a condition
 15  2 of bond, sentence, probation, parole, or a work permit, may
 15  3 require a person who has been charged with, pled guilty to,
 15  4 or been convicted of a crime in which the abuse of alcohol or
 15  5 a controlled substance was a contributing factor, including a
 15  6 second or subsequent offense of operating while intoxicated
 15  7 (OWI), to abstain from alcohol and controlled substances for
 15  8 a period of time.
 15  9    The program requires a person to be subject to testing to
 15 10 determine whether alcohol or a controlled substance is present
 15 11 in the person's body at least twice per day at a central
 15 12 location where an immediate sanction can be applied. Where
 15 13 such testing creates a documented hardship or is geographically
 15 14 impractical, an alternative method approved by DPS may be used.
 15 15    Hardship or geographic impracticality is determined by
 15 16 documentation and consideration of whether a testing device is
 15 17 available, whether the participant is capable of paying the
 15 18 fees and costs associated with the testing device, whether
 15 19 the participant is capable of wearing the testing device, and
 15 20 whether the participant fails to qualify for testing twice
 15 21 per day because the participant lives in a rural area, the
 15 22 participant's employment requires the participant's presence at
 15 23 a location remote from the testing location, or the participant
 15 24 has repeatedly violated the requirements of the program.
 15 25    The bill requires the program to be evidence=based.
 15 26    If a jurisdiction chooses to participate in the program, DPS
 15 27 shall assist the jurisdiction in setting up and administering
 15 28 the program. The participating jurisdiction shall establish
 15 29 testing locations and may designate a third party to provide
 15 30 testing services.
 15 31    Any efforts by DPS to alter or modify the core components
 15 32 of the program are required to include a documented strategy
 15 33 for achieving and measuring the effectiveness of the planned
 15 34 alteration or modification. Before the core components of the
 15 35 program can be altered or modified, a pilot program must be
 16  1 initiated and monitored.
 16  2    The bill allows DPS to adopt rules providing for the nature
 16  3 and manner of testing, establishing reasonable fees, providing
 16  4 for the application, acceptance, and use of public and private
 16  5 grants, gifts, and donations, establishing a process for the
 16  6 identification and management of indigent participants, and
 16  7 providing for the creation and administration of a stakeholder
 16  8 group to review and recommend changes to the program.
 16  9    The bill requires the amount of the fees to be set at
 16 10 an amount such that the fees collected in a participating
 16 11 jurisdiction are sufficient to pay for the costs of the program
 16 12 in the participating jurisdiction, including all costs to the
 16 13 state.
 16 14    The bill further requires DPS to provide for and approve
 16 15 the use of a program data management system to be used by DPS
 16 16 and all participating jurisdictions to manage testing, test
 16 17 events, test results, data access, fees, the collection of fee
 16 18 payments, and the submission and collection of any required
 16 19 reports. The bill provides for certain required features of
 16 20 the data management system.
 16 21    A court or a governmental entity in a participating
 16 22 jurisdiction may utilize the program. A court may condition
 16 23 any bond or pretrial release otherwise authorized by law for
 16 24 a person charged with a second or subsequent offense of OWI,
 16 25 or with any crime in which the abuse of alcohol or a controlled
 16 26 substance was a contributing factor, upon participation in the
 16 27 program and payment of the required fees. A court may also
 16 28 condition the granting of a suspended sentence or probation
 16 29 otherwise authorized by law for a person convicted of such a
 16 30 crime upon participation in the program and payment of the
 16 31 required fees.
 16 32    Likewise, the board of parole, the department of
 16 33 corrections, or a parole officer may condition parole otherwise
 16 34 authorized by law for a person convicted of such a crime upon
 16 35 participation in the program and payment of the required fees.
 17  1 The bill requires an order or directive placing a
 17  2 participant in the program to include the type of testing
 17  3 required to be administered and the length of time that the
 17  4 participant is required to remain in the program. At the
 17  5 time of enrollment, a representative of the law enforcement
 17  6 agency of a participating jurisdiction shall enter the
 17  7 participant's information into the data management system. The
 17  8 representative of the agency shall provide the participant with
 17  9 the appropriate materials required by the program, inform the
 17 10 participant that the participant's information may be shared
 17 11 for law enforcement and reporting purposes, and provide the
 17 12 participant with information related to the required testing,
 17 13 procedures, and fees.
 17 14    The bill provides that the law enforcement agency of a
 17 15 participating jurisdiction shall establish and maintain a
 17 16 sobriety program account, and collect the required fees. The
 17 17 law enforcement agency shall distribute a portion of the fees
 17 18 to any participating third=party designee in accordance with
 17 19 the agreement between the agency and the third=party designee,
 17 20 and the remainder of the fees collected shall be deposited
 17 21 in the participating jurisdiction's sobriety program account
 17 22 and shall be used only for the purposes of administering and
 17 23 operating the program.
 17 24    Upon the failure of a participant to submit to or pass a
 17 25 test under the program, a peace officer, probation officer, or
 17 26 parole officer shall complete a written statement establishing
 17 27 that the participant, in the judgment of the officer, violated
 17 28 a condition of release or a condition of the program by failing
 17 29 to submit to or pass a test.
 17 30    A peace officer shall immediately arrest the person without
 17 31 a warrant after completing or receiving the written statement.
 17 32 A person taken into custody shall appear before a court within
 17 33 a reasonable amount of time and shall not be released unless
 17 34 the person has made a personal appearance before a court.
 17 35    The bill provides that as an alternative to the installation
 18  1 of an ignition interlock device, a temporary restricted license
 18  2 for a person convicted of a second or subsequent OWI may be
 18  3 conditioned on participation in the program. Upon the failure
 18  4 of a participant to submit to or pass a test under the program,
 18  5 the court may notify the department of transportation (DOT)
 18  6 of the person's noncompliance and direct the DOT to withdraw
 18  7 the person's temporary restricted license and reinstate the
 18  8 remainder of the license suspension period.
       LSB 6005HV (1) 86
       ns/nh
 14 14 test under the program, a peace officer, probation officer, or
 14 15 parole officer shall complete a written statement establishing
 14 16 that the participant, in the judgment of the officer, violated
 14 17 a condition of release or a condition of the program by failing
 14 18 to submit to or pass a test. A peace officer shall immediately
 14 19 arrest the person without a warrant after completing or
 14 20 receiving the written statement.
 14 21    2.  A person taken into custody pursuant to this section
 14 22 shall appear before a court within a reasonable amount of time
 14 23 and shall not be released unless the person has made a personal
 14 24 appearance before a court.
 14 25    3.  The court may notify the department of transportation
 14 26 of the person's noncompliance and direct the department
 14 27 to withdraw any temporary restricted license issued to the
 14 28 person and reinstate the remainder of any applicable license
 14 29 suspension or revocation period provided by chapter 321J.

 14 24 appearance before a court.
 14 25    3.  The court may notify the department of transportation
 14 26 of the person's noncompliance and direct the department
 14 27 to withdraw any temporary restricted license issued to the
 14 28 person and reinstate the remainder of any applicable license
 14 29 suspension or revocation period provided by chapter 321J.
 14 30                           EXPLANATION
 14 31 The inclusion of this explanation does not constitute agreement with
 14 32 the explanation's substance by the members of the general assembly.
 14 33    This bill directs the department of public safety (DPS) to
 14 34 establish a statewide sobriety and drug monitoring program that
 14 35 is available 24 hours per day, seven days per week. Under
 15  1 the program, a court or governmental entity, as a condition
 15  2 of bond, sentence, probation, parole, or a work permit, may
 15  3 require a person who has been charged with, pled guilty to,
 15  4 or been convicted of a crime in which the abuse of alcohol or
 15  5 a controlled substance was a contributing factor, including a
 15  6 second or subsequent offense of operating while intoxicated
 15  7 (OWI), to abstain from alcohol and controlled substances for
 15  8 a period of time.
 15  9    The program requires a person to be subject to testing to
 15 10 determine whether alcohol or a controlled substance is present
 15 11 in the person's body at least twice per day at a central
 15 12 location where an immediate sanction can be applied. Where
 15 13 such testing creates a documented hardship or is geographically
 15 14 impractical, an alternative method approved by DPS may be used.
 15 15    Hardship or geographic impracticality is determined by
 15 16 documentation and consideration of whether a testing device is
 15 17 available, whether the participant is capable of paying the
 15 18 fees and costs associated with the testing device, whether
 15 19 the participant is capable of wearing the testing device, and
 15 20 whether the participant fails to qualify for testing twice
 15 21 per day because the participant lives in a rural area, the
 15 22 participant's employment requires the participant's presence at
 15 23 a location remote from the testing location, or the participant
 15 24 has repeatedly violated the requirements of the program.
 15 25    The bill requires the program to be evidence=based.
 15 26    If a jurisdiction chooses to participate in the program, DPS
 15 27 shall assist the jurisdiction in setting up and administering
 15 28 the program. The participating jurisdiction shall establish
 15 29 testing locations and may designate a third party to provide
 15 30 testing services.
 15 31    Any efforts by DPS to alter or modify the core components
 15 32 of the program are required to include a documented strategy
 15 33 for achieving and measuring the effectiveness of the planned
 15 34 alteration or modification. Before the core components of the
 15 35 program can be altered or modified, a pilot program must be
 16  1 initiated and monitored.
 16  2    The bill allows DPS to adopt rules providing for the nature
 16  3 and manner of testing, establishing reasonable fees, providing
 16  4 for the application, acceptance, and use of public and private
 16  5 grants, gifts, and donations, establishing a process for the
 16  6 identification and management of indigent participants, and
 16  7 providing for the creation and administration of a stakeholder
 16  8 group to review and recommend changes to the program.
 16  9    The bill requires the amount of the fees to be set at
 16 10 an amount such that the fees collected in a participating
 16 11 jurisdiction are sufficient to pay for the costs of the program
 16 12 in the participating jurisdiction, including all costs to the
 16 13 state.
 16 14    The bill further requires DPS to provide for and approve
 16 15 the use of a program data management system to be used by DPS
 16 16 and all participating jurisdictions to manage testing, test
 16 17 events, test results, data access, fees, the collection of fee
 16 18 payments, and the submission and collection of any required
 16 19 reports. The bill provides for certain required features of
 16 20 the data management system.
 16 21    A court or a governmental entity in a participating
 16 22 jurisdiction may utilize the program. A court may condition
 16 23 any bond or pretrial release otherwise authorized by law for
 16 24 a person charged with a second or subsequent offense of OWI,
 16 25 or with any crime in which the abuse of alcohol or a controlled
 16 26 substance was a contributing factor, upon participation in the
 16 27 program and payment of the required fees. A court may also
 16 28 condition the granting of a suspended sentence or probation
 16 29 otherwise authorized by law for a person convicted of such a
 16 30 crime upon participation in the program and payment of the
 16 31 required fees.
 16 32    Likewise, the board of parole, the department of
 16 33 corrections, or a parole officer may condition parole otherwise
 16 34 authorized by law for a person convicted of such a crime upon
 16 35 participation in the program and payment of the required fees.
 17  1 The bill requires an order or directive placing a
 17  2 participant in the program to include the type of testing
 17  3 required to be administered and the length of time that the
 17  4 participant is required to remain in the program. At the
 17  5 time of enrollment, a representative of the law enforcement
 17  6 agency of a participating jurisdiction shall enter the
 17  7 participant's information into the data management system. The
 17  8 representative of the agency shall provide the participant with
 17  9 the appropriate materials required by the program, inform the
 17 10 participant that the participant's information may be shared
 17 11 for law enforcement and reporting purposes, and provide the
 17 12 participant with information related to the required testing,
 17 13 procedures, and fees.
 17 14    The bill provides that the law enforcement agency of a
 17 15 participating jurisdiction shall establish and maintain a
 17 16 sobriety program account, and collect the required fees. The
 17 17 law enforcement agency shall distribute a portion of the fees
 17 18 to any participating third=party designee in accordance with
 17 19 the agreement between the agency and the third=party designee,
 17 20 and the remainder of the fees collected shall be deposited
 17 21 in the participating jurisdiction's sobriety program account
 17 22 and shall be used only for the purposes of administering and
 17 23 operating the program.
 17 24    Upon the failure of a participant to submit to or pass a
 17 25 test under the program, a peace officer, probation officer, or
 17 26 parole officer shall complete a written statement establishing
 17 27 that the participant, in the judgment of the officer, violated
 17 28 a condition of release or a condition of the program by failing
 17 29 to submit to or pass a test.
 17 30    A peace officer shall immediately arrest the person without
 17 31 a warrant after completing or receiving the written statement.
 17 32 A person taken into custody shall appear before a court within
 17 33 a reasonable amount of time and shall not be released unless
 17 34 the person has made a personal appearance before a court.
 17 35    The bill provides that as an alternative to the installation
 18  1 of an ignition interlock device, a temporary restricted license
 18  2 for a person convicted of a second or subsequent OWI may be
 18  3 conditioned on participation in the program. Upon the failure
 18  4 of a participant to submit to or pass a test under the program,
 18  5 the court may notify the department of transportation (DOT)
 18  6 of the person's noncompliance and direct the DOT to withdraw
 18  7 the person's temporary restricted license and reinstate the
 18  8 remainder of the license suspension period.
       LSB 6005HV (1) 86
       ns/nh
 14 17 a condition of release or a condition of the program by failing
 14 18 to submit to or pass a test. A peace officer shall immediately
 14 19 arrest the person without a warrant after completing or
 14 20 receiving the written statement.
 14 21    2.  A person taken into custody pursuant to this section
 14 22 shall appear before a court within a reasonable amount of time
 14 23 and shall not be released unless the person has made a personal
 14 24 appearance before a court.
 14 25    3.  The court may notify the department of transportation
 14 26 of the person's noncompliance and direct the department
 14 27 to withdraw any temporary restricted license issued to the
 14 28 person and reinstate the remainder of any applicable license
 14 29 suspension or revocation period provided by chapter 321J.

 14 32 the explanation's substance by the members of the general assembly.

 16 31 required fees.

 16 35 participation in the program and payment of the required fees.

 17  5 time of enrollment, a representative of the law enforcement

 15 22 participant's employment requires the participant's presence at
 15 23 a location remote from the testing location, or the participant
 15 24 has repeatedly violated the requirements of the program.
 15 25    The bill requires the program to be evidence=based.
 15 26    If a jurisdiction chooses to participate in the program, DPS
 15 27 shall assist the jurisdiction in setting up and administering
 15 28 the program. The participating jurisdiction shall establish
 15 29 testing locations and may designate a third party to provide
 15 30 testing services.
 15 31    Any efforts by DPS to alter or modify the core components
 15 32 of the program are required to include a documented strategy
 15 33 for achieving and measuring the effectiveness of the planned
 15 34 alteration or modification. Before the core components of the
 15 35 program can be altered or modified, a pilot program must be
 16  1 initiated and monitored.
 16  2    The bill allows DPS to adopt rules providing for the nature
 16  3 and manner of testing, establishing reasonable fees, providing
 16  4 for the application, acceptance, and use of public and private
 16  5 grants, gifts, and donations, establishing a process for the
 16  6 identification and management of indigent participants, and
 16  7 providing for the creation and administration of a stakeholder
 16  8 group to review and recommend changes to the program.
 16  9    The bill requires the amount of the fees to be set at
 16 10 an amount such that the fees collected in a participating
 16 11 jurisdiction are sufficient to pay for the costs of the program
 16 12 in the participating jurisdiction, including all costs to the
 16 13 state.
 16 14    The bill further requires DPS to provide for and approve
 16 15 the use of a program data management system to be used by DPS
 16 16 and all participating jurisdictions to manage testing, test
 16 17 events, test results, data access, fees, the collection of fee
 16 18 payments, and the submission and collection of any required
 16 19 reports. The bill provides for certain required features of
 16 20 the data management system.
 16 21    A court or a governmental entity in a participating
 16 22 jurisdiction may utilize the program. A court may condition
 16 23 any bond or pretrial release otherwise authorized by law for
 16 24 a person charged with a second or subsequent offense of OWI,
 16 25 or with any crime in which the abuse of alcohol or a controlled
 16 26 substance was a contributing factor, upon participation in the
 16 27 program and payment of the required fees. A court may also
 16 28 condition the granting of a suspended sentence or probation
 16 29 otherwise authorized by law for a person convicted of such a
 16 30 crime upon participation in the program and payment of the
 16 31 required fees.
 16 32    Likewise, the board of parole, the department of
 16 33 corrections, or a parole officer may condition parole otherwise
 16 34 authorized by law for a person convicted of such a crime upon
 16 35 participation in the program and payment of the required fees.
 17  1 The bill requires an order or directive placing a
 17  2 participant in the program to include the type of testing
 17  3 required to be administered and the length of time that the
 17  4 participant is required to remain in the program. At the
 17  5 time of enrollment, a representative of the law enforcement
 17  6 agency of a participating jurisdiction shall enter the
 17  7 participant's information into the data management system. The
 17  8 representative of the agency shall provide the participant with
 17  9 the appropriate materials required by the program, inform the
 17 10 participant that the participant's information may be shared
 17 11 for law enforcement and reporting purposes, and provide the
 17 12 participant with information related to the required testing,
 17 13 procedures, and fees.
 17 14    The bill provides that the law enforcement agency of a
 17 15 participating jurisdiction shall establish and maintain a
 17 16 sobriety program account, and collect the required fees. The
 17 17 law enforcement agency shall distribute a portion of the fees
 17 18 to any participating third=party designee in accordance with
 17 19 the agreement between the agency and the third=party designee,
 17 20 and the remainder of the fees collected shall be deposited
 17 21 in the participating jurisdiction's sobriety program account
 17 22 and shall be used only for the purposes of administering and
 17 23 operating the program.
 17 24    Upon the failure of a participant to submit to or pass a
 17 25 test under the program, a peace officer, probation officer, or
 17 26 parole officer shall complete a written statement establishing
 17 27 that the participant, in the judgment of the officer, violated
 17 28 a condition of release or a condition of the program by failing
 17 29 to submit to or pass a test.
 17 30    A peace officer shall immediately arrest the person without
 17 31 a warrant after completing or receiving the written statement.
 17 32 A person taken into custody shall appear before a court within
 17 33 a reasonable amount of time and shall not be released unless
 17 34 the person has made a personal appearance before a court.
 17 35    The bill provides that as an alternative to the installation
 18  1 of an ignition interlock device, a temporary restricted license
 18  2 for a person convicted of a second or subsequent OWI may be
 18  3 conditioned on participation in the program. Upon the failure
 18  4 of a participant to submit to or pass a test under the program,
 18  5 the court may notify the department of transportation (DOT)
 18  6 of the person's noncompliance and direct the DOT to withdraw
 18  7 the person's temporary restricted license and reinstate the
 18  8 remainder of the license suspension period.
       LSB 6005HV (1) 86
       ns/nh
 14 21    2.  A person taken into custody pursuant to this section
 14 22 shall appear before a court within a reasonable amount of time
 14 23 and shall not be released unless the person has made a personal
 14 24 appearance before a court.
 14 25    3.  The court may notify the department of transportation
 14 26 of the person's noncompliance and direct the department
 14 27 to withdraw any temporary restricted license issued to the
 14 28 person and reinstate the remainder of any applicable license
 14 29 suspension or revocation period provided by chapter 321J.
 14 30                           EXPLANATION
 14 31 The inclusion of this explanation does not constitute agreement with
 14 32 the explanation's substance by the members of the general assembly.
 14 33    This bill directs the department of public safety (DPS) to
 14 34 establish a statewide sobriety and drug monitoring program that
 14 35 is available 24 hours per day, seven days per week. Under
 15  1 the program, a court or governmental entity, as a condition
 15  2 of bond, sentence, probation, parole, or a work permit, may
 15  3 require a person who has been charged with, pled guilty to,
 15  4 or been convicted of a crime in which the abuse of alcohol or
 15  5 a controlled substance was a contributing factor, including a
 15  6 second or subsequent offense of operating while intoxicated
 15  7 (OWI), to abstain from alcohol and controlled substances for
 15  8 a period of time.
 15  9    The program requires a person to be subject to testing to
 15 10 determine whether alcohol or a controlled substance is present
 15 11 in the person's body at least twice per day at a central
 15 12 location where an immediate sanction can be applied. Where
 15 13 such testing creates a documented hardship or is geographically
 15 14 impractical, an alternative method approved by DPS may be used.
 15 15    Hardship or geographic impracticality is determined by
 15 16 documentation and consideration of whether a testing device is
 15 17 available, whether the participant is capable of paying the
 15 18 fees and costs associated with the testing device, whether
 15 19 the participant is capable of wearing the testing device, and
 15 20 whether the participant fails to qualify for testing twice
 15 21 per day because the participant lives in a rural area, the
 15 22 participant's employment requires the participant's presence at
 15 23 a location remote from the testing location, or the participant
 15 24 has repeatedly violated the requirements of the program.
 15 25    The bill requires the program to be evidence=based.
 15 26    If a jurisdiction chooses to participate in the program, DPS
 15 27 shall assist the jurisdiction in setting up and administering
 15 28 the program. The participating jurisdiction shall establish
 15 29 testing locations and may designate a third party to provide
 15 30 testing services.
 15 31    Any efforts by DPS to alter or modify the core components
 15 32 of the program are required to include a documented strategy
 15 33 for achieving and measuring the effectiveness of the planned
 15 34 alteration or modification. Before the core components of the
 15 35 program can be altered or modified, a pilot program must be
 16  1 initiated and monitored.
 16  2    The bill allows DPS to adopt rules providing for the nature
 16  3 and manner of testing, establishing reasonable fees, providing
 16  4 for the application, acceptance, and use of public and private
 16  5 grants, gifts, and donations, establishing a process for the
 16  6 identification and management of indigent participants, and
 16  7 providing for the creation and administration of a stakeholder
 16  8 group to review and recommend changes to the program.
 16  9    The bill requires the amount of the fees to be set at
 16 10 an amount such that the fees collected in a participating
 16 11 jurisdiction are sufficient to pay for the costs of the program
 16 12 in the participating jurisdiction, including all costs to the
 16 13 state.
 16 14    The bill further requires DPS to provide for and approve
 16 15 the use of a program data management system to be used by DPS
 16 16 and all participating jurisdictions to manage testing, test
 16 17 events, test results, data access, fees, the collection of fee
 16 18 payments, and the submission and collection of any required
 16 19 reports. The bill provides for certain required features of
 16 20 the data management system.
 16 21    A court or a governmental entity in a participating
 16 22 jurisdiction may utilize the program. A court may condition
 16 23 any bond or pretrial release otherwise authorized by law for
 16 24 a person charged with a second or subsequent offense of OWI,
 16 25 or with any crime in which the abuse of alcohol or a controlled
 16 26 substance was a contributing factor, upon participation in the
 16 27 program and payment of the required fees. A court may also
 16 28 condition the granting of a suspended sentence or probation
 16 29 otherwise authorized by law for a person convicted of such a
 16 30 crime upon participation in the program and payment of the
 16 31 required fees.
 16 32    Likewise, the board of parole, the department of
 16 33 corrections, or a parole officer may condition parole otherwise
 16 34 authorized by law for a person convicted of such a crime upon
 16 35 participation in the program and payment of the required fees.
 17  1 The bill requires an order or directive placing a
 17  2 participant in the program to include the type of testing
 17  3 required to be administered and the length of time that the
 17  4 participant is required to remain in the program. At the
 17  5 time of enrollment, a representative of the law enforcement
 17  6 agency of a participating jurisdiction shall enter the
 17  7 participant's information into the data management system. The
 17  8 representative of the agency shall provide the participant with
 17  9 the appropriate materials required by the program, inform the
 17 10 participant that the participant's information may be shared
 17 11 for law enforcement and reporting purposes, and provide the
 17 12 participant with information related to the required testing,
 17 13 procedures, and fees.
 17 14    The bill provides that the law enforcement agency of a
 17 15 participating jurisdiction shall establish and maintain a
 17 16 sobriety program account, and collect the required fees. The
 17 17 law enforcement agency shall distribute a portion of the fees
 17 18 to any participating third=party designee in accordance with
 17 19 the agreement between the agency and the third=party designee,
 17 20 and the remainder of the fees collected shall be deposited
 17 21 in the participating jurisdiction's sobriety program account
 17 22 and shall be used only for the purposes of administering and
 17 23 operating the program.
 17 24    Upon the failure of a participant to submit to or pass a
 17 25 test under the program, a peace officer, probation officer, or
 17 26 parole officer shall complete a written statement establishing
 17 27 that the participant, in the judgment of the officer, violated
 17 28 a condition of release or a condition of the program by failing
 17 29 to submit to or pass a test.
 17 30    A peace officer shall immediately arrest the person without
 17 31 a warrant after completing or receiving the written statement.
 17 32 A person taken into custody shall appear before a court within
 17 33 a reasonable amount of time and shall not be released unless
 17 34 the person has made a personal appearance before a court.
 17 35    The bill provides that as an alternative to the installation
 18  1 of an ignition interlock device, a temporary restricted license
 18  2 for a person convicted of a second or subsequent OWI may be
 18  3 conditioned on participation in the program. Upon the failure
 18  4 of a participant to submit to or pass a test under the program,
 18  5 the court may notify the department of transportation (DOT)
 18  6 of the person's noncompliance and direct the DOT to withdraw
 18  7 the person's temporary restricted license and reinstate the
 18  8 remainder of the license suspension period.
       LSB 6005HV (1) 86
       ns/nh
 14 22 shall appear before a court within a reasonable amount of time
 14 23 and shall not be released unless the person has made a personal
 14 24 appearance before a court.
 14 25    3.  The court may notify the department of transportation
 14 26 of the person's noncompliance and direct the department
 14 27 to withdraw any temporary restricted license issued to the
 14 28 person and reinstate the remainder of any applicable license
 14 29 suspension or revocation period provided by chapter 321J.

 17  2 participant in the program to include the type of testing
 17  3 required to be administered and the length of time that the
 17  4 participant is required to remain in the program. At the
 17  5 time of enrollment, a representative of the law enforcement
 17  6 agency of a participating jurisdiction shall enter the
 17  7 participant's information into the data management system. The
 17  8 representative of the agency shall provide the participant with
 17  9 the appropriate materials required by the program, inform the
 17 10 participant that the participant's information may be shared
 17 11 for law enforcement and reporting purposes, and provide the
 17 12 participant with information related to the required testing,
 17 13 procedures, and fees.
 17 14    The bill provides that the law enforcement agency of a
 17 15 participating jurisdiction shall establish and maintain a
 17 16 sobriety program account, and collect the required fees. The
 17 17 law enforcement agency shall distribute a portion of the fees
 17 18 to any participating third=party designee in accordance with
 17 19 the agreement between the agency and the third=party designee,
 17 20 and the remainder of the fees collected shall be deposited
 17 21 in the participating jurisdiction's sobriety program account
 17 22 and shall be used only for the purposes of administering and
 17 23 operating the program.
 17 24    Upon the failure of a participant to submit to or pass a
 17 25 test under the program, a peace officer, probation officer, or
 17 26 parole officer shall complete a written statement establishing
 17 27 that the participant, in the judgment of the officer, violated
 17 28 a condition of release or a condition of the program by failing
 17 29 to submit to or pass a test.
 17 30    A peace officer shall immediately arrest the person without
 17 31 a warrant after completing or receiving the written statement.
 17 32 A person taken into custody shall appear before a court within
 17 33 a reasonable amount of time and shall not be released unless
 17 34 the person has made a personal appearance before a court.
 17 35    The bill provides that as an alternative to the installation
 18  1 of an ignition interlock device, a temporary restricted license
 18  2 for a person convicted of a second or subsequent OWI may be
 18  3 conditioned on participation in the program. Upon the failure
 18  4 of a participant to submit to or pass a test under the program,
 18  5 the court may notify the department of transportation (DOT)
 18  6 of the person's noncompliance and direct the DOT to withdraw
 18  7 the person's temporary restricted license and reinstate the
 18  8 remainder of the license suspension period.
       LSB 6005HV (1) 86
       ns/nh
 14 25    3.  The court may notify the department of transportation
 14 26 of the person's noncompliance and direct the department
 14 27 to withdraw any temporary restricted license issued to the
 14 28 person and reinstate the remainder of any applicable license
 14 29 suspension or revocation period provided by chapter 321J.
 14 30                           EXPLANATION
 14 31 The inclusion of this explanation does not constitute agreement with
 14 32 the explanation's substance by the members of the general assembly.
 14 33    This bill directs the department of public safety (DPS) to
 14 34 establish a statewide sobriety and drug monitoring program that
 14 35 is available 24 hours per day, seven days per week. Under
 15  1 the program, a court or governmental entity, as a condition
 15  2 of bond, sentence, probation, parole, or a work permit, may
 15  3 require a person who has been charged with, pled guilty to,
 15  4 or been convicted of a crime in which the abuse of alcohol or
 15  5 a controlled substance was a contributing factor, including a
 15  6 second or subsequent offense of operating while intoxicated
 15  7 (OWI), to abstain from alcohol and controlled substances for
 15  8 a period of time.
 15  9    The program requires a person to be subject to testing to
 15 10 determine whether alcohol or a controlled substance is present
 15 11 in the person's body at least twice per day at a central
 15 12 location where an immediate sanction can be applied. Where
 15 13 such testing creates a documented hardship or is geographically
 15 14 impractical, an alternative method approved by DPS may be used.
 15 15    Hardship or geographic impracticality is determined by
 15 16 documentation and consideration of whether a testing device is
 15 17 available, whether the participant is capable of paying the
 15 18 fees and costs associated with the testing device, whether
 15 19 the participant is capable of wearing the testing device, and
 15 20 whether the participant fails to qualify for testing twice
 15 21 per day because the participant lives in a rural area, the
 15 22 participant's employment requires the participant's presence at
 15 23 a location remote from the testing location, or the participant
 15 24 has repeatedly violated the requirements of the program.
 15 25    The bill requires the program to be evidence=based.
 15 26    If a jurisdiction chooses to participate in the program, DPS
 15 27 shall assist the jurisdiction in setting up and administering
 15 28 the program. The participating jurisdiction shall establish
 15 29 testing locations and may designate a third party to provide
 15 30 testing services.
 15 31    Any efforts by DPS to alter or modify the core components
 15 32 of the program are required to include a documented strategy
 15 33 for achieving and measuring the effectiveness of the planned
 15 34 alteration or modification. Before the core components of the
 15 35 program can be altered or modified, a pilot program must be
 16  1 initiated and monitored.
 16  2    The bill allows DPS to adopt rules providing for the nature
 16  3 and manner of testing, establishing reasonable fees, providing
 16  4 for the application, acceptance, and use of public and private
 16  5 grants, gifts, and donations, establishing a process for the
 16  6 identification and management of indigent participants, and
 16  7 providing for the creation and administration of a stakeholder
 16  8 group to review and recommend changes to the program.
 16  9    The bill requires the amount of the fees to be set at
 16 10 an amount such that the fees collected in a participating
 16 11 jurisdiction are sufficient to pay for the costs of the program
 16 12 in the participating jurisdiction, including all costs to the
 16 13 state.
 16 14    The bill further requires DPS to provide for and approve
 16 15 the use of a program data management system to be used by DPS
 16 16 and all participating jurisdictions to manage testing, test
 16 17 events, test results, data access, fees, the collection of fee
 16 18 payments, and the submission and collection of any required
 16 19 reports. The bill provides for certain required features of
 16 20 the data management system.
 16 21    A court or a governmental entity in a participating
 16 22 jurisdiction may utilize the program. A court may condition
 16 23 any bond or pretrial release otherwise authorized by law for
 16 24 a person charged with a second or subsequent offense of OWI,
 16 25 or with any crime in which the abuse of alcohol or a controlled
 16 26 substance was a contributing factor, upon participation in the
 16 27 program and payment of the required fees. A court may also
 16 28 condition the granting of a suspended sentence or probation
 16 29 otherwise authorized by law for a person convicted of such a
 16 30 crime upon participation in the program and payment of the
 16 31 required fees.
 16 32    Likewise, the board of parole, the department of
 16 33 corrections, or a parole officer may condition parole otherwise
 16 34 authorized by law for a person convicted of such a crime upon
 16 35 participation in the program and payment of the required fees.
 17  1 The bill requires an order or directive placing a
 17  2 participant in the program to include the type of testing
 17  3 required to be administered and the length of time that the
 17  4 participant is required to remain in the program. At the
 17  5 time of enrollment, a representative of the law enforcement
 17  6 agency of a participating jurisdiction shall enter the
 17  7 participant's information into the data management system. The
 17  8 representative of the agency shall provide the participant with
 17  9 the appropriate materials required by the program, inform the
 17 10 participant that the participant's information may be shared
 17 11 for law enforcement and reporting purposes, and provide the
 17 12 participant with information related to the required testing,
 17 13 procedures, and fees.
 17 14    The bill provides that the law enforcement agency of a
 17 15 participating jurisdiction shall establish and maintain a
 17 16 sobriety program account, and collect the required fees. The
 17 17 law enforcement agency shall distribute a portion of the fees
 17 18 to any participating third=party designee in accordance with
 17 19 the agreement between the agency and the third=party designee,
 17 20 and the remainder of the fees collected shall be deposited
 17 21 in the participating jurisdiction's sobriety program account
 17 22 and shall be used only for the purposes of administering and
 17 23 operating the program.
 17 24    Upon the failure of a participant to submit to or pass a
 17 25 test under the program, a peace officer, probation officer, or
 17 26 parole officer shall complete a written statement establishing
 17 27 that the participant, in the judgment of the officer, violated
 17 28 a condition of release or a condition of the program by failing
 17 29 to submit to or pass a test.
 17 30    A peace officer shall immediately arrest the person without
 17 31 a warrant after completing or receiving the written statement.
 17 32 A person taken into custody shall appear before a court within
 17 33 a reasonable amount of time and shall not be released unless
 17 34 the person has made a personal appearance before a court.
 17 35    The bill provides that as an alternative to the installation
 18  1 of an ignition interlock device, a temporary restricted license
 18  2 for a person convicted of a second or subsequent OWI may be
 18  3 conditioned on participation in the program. Upon the failure
 18  4 of a participant to submit to or pass a test under the program,
 18  5 the court may notify the department of transportation (DOT)
 18  6 of the person's noncompliance and direct the DOT to withdraw
 18  7 the person's temporary restricted license and reinstate the
 18  8 remainder of the license suspension period.
       LSB 6005HV (1) 86
       ns/nh
 14 26 of the person's noncompliance and direct the department
 14 27 to withdraw any temporary restricted license issued to the
 14 28 person and reinstate the remainder of any applicable license
 14 29 suspension or revocation period provided by chapter 321J.

 14 32 the explanation's substance by the members of the general assembly.

 15 13 such testing creates a documented hardship or is geographically
 15 14 impractical, an alternative method approved by DPS may be used.
 15 15    Hardship or geographic impracticality is determined by
 15 16 documentation and consideration of whether a testing device is
 15 17 available, whether the participant is capable of paying the
 15 18 fees and costs associated with the testing device, whether
 15 19 the participant is capable of wearing the testing device, and
 15 20 whether the participant fails to qualify for testing twice
 15 21 per day because the participant lives in a rural area, the
 15 22 participant's employment requires the participant's presence at
 15 23 a location remote from the testing location, or the participant
 15 24 has repeatedly violated the requirements of the program.
 15 25    The bill requires the program to be evidence=based.
 15 26    If a jurisdiction chooses to participate in the program, DPS
 15 27 shall assist the jurisdiction in setting up and administering
 15 28 the program. The participating jurisdiction shall establish
 15 29 testing locations and may designate a third party to provide
 15 30 testing services.
 15 31    Any efforts by DPS to alter or modify the core components
 15 32 of the program are required to include a documented strategy
 15 33 for achieving and measuring the effectiveness of the planned
 15 34 alteration or modification. Before the core components of the
 15 35 program can be altered or modified, a pilot program must be
 16  1 initiated and monitored.
 16  2    The bill allows DPS to adopt rules providing for the nature
 16  3 and manner of testing, establishing reasonable fees, providing
 16  4 for the application, acceptance, and use of public and private
 16  5 grants, gifts, and donations, establishing a process for the
 16  6 identification and management of indigent participants, and
 16  7 providing for the creation and administration of a stakeholder
 16  8 group to review and recommend changes to the program.
 16  9    The bill requires the amount of the fees to be set at
 16 10 an amount such that the fees collected in a participating
 16 11 jurisdiction are sufficient to pay for the costs of the program
 16 12 in the participating jurisdiction, including all costs to the
 16 13 state.
 16 14    The bill further requires DPS to provide for and approve
 16 15 the use of a program data management system to be used by DPS
 16 16 and all participating jurisdictions to manage testing, test
 16 17 events, test results, data access, fees, the collection of fee
 16 18 payments, and the submission and collection of any required
 16 19 reports. The bill provides for certain required features of
 16 20 the data management system.
 16 21    A court or a governmental entity in a participating
 16 22 jurisdiction may utilize the program. A court may condition
 16 23 any bond or pretrial release otherwise authorized by law for
 16 24 a person charged with a second or subsequent offense of OWI,
 16 25 or with any crime in which the abuse of alcohol or a controlled
 16 26 substance was a contributing factor, upon participation in the
 16 27 program and payment of the required fees. A court may also
 16 28 condition the granting of a suspended sentence or probation
 16 29 otherwise authorized by law for a person convicted of such a
 16 30 crime upon participation in the program and payment of the
 16 31 required fees.
 16 32    Likewise, the board of parole, the department of
 16 33 corrections, or a parole officer may condition parole otherwise
 16 34 authorized by law for a person convicted of such a crime upon
 16 35 participation in the program and payment of the required fees.
 17  1 The bill requires an order or directive placing a
 17  2 participant in the program to include the type of testing
 17  3 required to be administered and the length of time that the
 17  4 participant is required to remain in the program. At the
 17  5 time of enrollment, a representative of the law enforcement
 17  6 agency of a participating jurisdiction shall enter the
 17  7 participant's information into the data management system. The
 17  8 representative of the agency shall provide the participant with
 17  9 the appropriate materials required by the program, inform the
 17 10 participant that the participant's information may be shared
 17 11 for law enforcement and reporting purposes, and provide the
 17 12 participant with information related to the required testing,
 17 13 procedures, and fees.
 17 14    The bill provides that the law enforcement agency of a
 17 15 participating jurisdiction shall establish and maintain a
 17 16 sobriety program account, and collect the required fees. The
 17 17 law enforcement agency shall distribute a portion of the fees
 17 18 to any participating third=party designee in accordance with
 17 19 the agreement between the agency and the third=party designee,
 17 20 and the remainder of the fees collected shall be deposited
 17 21 in the participating jurisdiction's sobriety program account
 17 22 and shall be used only for the purposes of administering and
 17 23 operating the program.
 17 24    Upon the failure of a participant to submit to or pass a
 17 25 test under the program, a peace officer, probation officer, or
 17 26 parole officer shall complete a written statement establishing
 17 27 that the participant, in the judgment of the officer, violated
 17 28 a condition of release or a condition of the program by failing
 17 29 to submit to or pass a test.
 17 30    A peace officer shall immediately arrest the person without
 17 31 a warrant after completing or receiving the written statement.
 17 32 A person taken into custody shall appear before a court within
 17 33 a reasonable amount of time and shall not be released unless
 17 34 the person has made a personal appearance before a court.
 17 35    The bill provides that as an alternative to the installation
 18  1 of an ignition interlock device, a temporary restricted license
 18  2 for a person convicted of a second or subsequent OWI may be
 18  3 conditioned on participation in the program. Upon the failure
 18  4 of a participant to submit to or pass a test under the program,
 18  5 the court may notify the department of transportation (DOT)
 18  6 of the person's noncompliance and direct the DOT to withdraw
 18  7 the person's temporary restricted license and reinstate the
 18  8 remainder of the license suspension period.
       LSB 6005HV (1) 86
       ns/nh
 14 30                           EXPLANATION
 14 31 The inclusion of this explanation does not constitute agreement with
 14 32 the explanation's substance by the members of the general assembly.
 14 33    This bill directs the department of public safety (DPS) to
 14 34 establish a statewide sobriety and drug monitoring program that
 14 35 is available 24 hours per day, seven days per week. Under
 15  1 the program, a court or governmental entity, as a condition
 15  2 of bond, sentence, probation, parole, or a work permit, may
 15  3 require a person who has been charged with, pled guilty to,
 15  4 or been convicted of a crime in which the abuse of alcohol or
 15  5 a controlled substance was a contributing factor, including a
 15  6 second or subsequent offense of operating while intoxicated
 15  7 (OWI), to abstain from alcohol and controlled substances for
 15  8 a period of time.
 15  9    The program requires a person to be subject to testing to
 15 10 determine whether alcohol or a controlled substance is present
 15 11 in the person's body at least twice per day at a central
 15 12 location where an immediate sanction can be applied. Where
 15 13 such testing creates a documented hardship or is geographically
 15 14 impractical, an alternative method approved by DPS may be used.
 15 15    Hardship or geographic impracticality is determined by
 15 16 documentation and consideration of whether a testing device is
 15 17 available, whether the participant is capable of paying the
 15 18 fees and costs associated with the testing device, whether
 15 19 the participant is capable of wearing the testing device, and
 15 20 whether the participant fails to qualify for testing twice
 15 21 per day because the participant lives in a rural area, the
 15 22 participant's employment requires the participant's presence at
 15 23 a location remote from the testing location, or the participant
 15 24 has repeatedly violated the requirements of the program.
 15 25    The bill requires the program to be evidence=based.
 15 26    If a jurisdiction chooses to participate in the program, DPS
 15 27 shall assist the jurisdiction in setting up and administering
 15 28 the program. The participating jurisdiction shall establish
 15 29 testing locations and may designate a third party to provide
 15 30 testing services.
 15 31    Any efforts by DPS to alter or modify the core components
 15 32 of the program are required to include a documented strategy
 15 33 for achieving and measuring the effectiveness of the planned
 15 34 alteration or modification. Before the core components of the
 15 35 program can be altered or modified, a pilot program must be
 16  1 initiated and monitored.
 16  2    The bill allows DPS to adopt rules providing for the nature
 16  3 and manner of testing, establishing reasonable fees, providing
 16  4 for the application, acceptance, and use of public and private
 16  5 grants, gifts, and donations, establishing a process for the
 16  6 identification and management of indigent participants, and
 16  7 providing for the creation and administration of a stakeholder
 16  8 group to review and recommend changes to the program.
 16  9    The bill requires the amount of the fees to be set at
 16 10 an amount such that the fees collected in a participating
 16 11 jurisdiction are sufficient to pay for the costs of the program
 16 12 in the participating jurisdiction, including all costs to the
 16 13 state.
 16 14    The bill further requires DPS to provide for and approve
 16 15 the use of a program data management system to be used by DPS
 16 16 and all participating jurisdictions to manage testing, test
 16 17 events, test results, data access, fees, the collection of fee
 16 18 payments, and the submission and collection of any required
 16 19 reports. The bill provides for certain required features of
 16 20 the data management system.
 16 21    A court or a governmental entity in a participating
 16 22 jurisdiction may utilize the program. A court may condition
 16 23 any bond or pretrial release otherwise authorized by law for
 16 24 a person charged with a second or subsequent offense of OWI,
 16 25 or with any crime in which the abuse of alcohol or a controlled
 16 26 substance was a contributing factor, upon participation in the
 16 27 program and payment of the required fees. A court may also
 16 28 condition the granting of a suspended sentence or probation
 16 29 otherwise authorized by law for a person convicted of such a
 16 30 crime upon participation in the program and payment of the
 16 31 required fees.
 16 32    Likewise, the board of parole, the department of
 16 33 corrections, or a parole officer may condition parole otherwise
 16 34 authorized by law for a person convicted of such a crime upon
 16 35 participation in the program and payment of the required fees.
 17  1 The bill requires an order or directive placing a
 17  2 participant in the program to include the type of testing
 17  3 required to be administered and the length of time that the
 17  4 participant is required to remain in the program. At the
 17  5 time of enrollment, a representative of the law enforcement
 17  6 agency of a participating jurisdiction shall enter the
 17  7 participant's information into the data management system. The
 17  8 representative of the agency shall provide the participant with
 17  9 the appropriate materials required by the program, inform the
 17 10 participant that the participant's information may be shared
 17 11 for law enforcement and reporting purposes, and provide the
 17 12 participant with information related to the required testing,
 17 13 procedures, and fees.
 17 14    The bill provides that the law enforcement agency of a
 17 15 participating jurisdiction shall establish and maintain a
 17 16 sobriety program account, and collect the required fees. The
 17 17 law enforcement agency shall distribute a portion of the fees
 17 18 to any participating third=party designee in accordance with
 17 19 the agreement between the agency and the third=party designee,
 17 20 and the remainder of the fees collected shall be deposited
 17 21 in the participating jurisdiction's sobriety program account
 17 22 and shall be used only for the purposes of administering and
 17 23 operating the program.
 17 24    Upon the failure of a participant to submit to or pass a
 17 25 test under the program, a peace officer, probation officer, or
 17 26 parole officer shall complete a written statement establishing
 17 27 that the participant, in the judgment of the officer, violated
 17 28 a condition of release or a condition of the program by failing
 17 29 to submit to or pass a test.
 17 30    A peace officer shall immediately arrest the person without
 17 31 a warrant after completing or receiving the written statement.
 17 32 A person taken into custody shall appear before a court within
 17 33 a reasonable amount of time and shall not be released unless
 17 34 the person has made a personal appearance before a court.
 17 35    The bill provides that as an alternative to the installation
 18  1 of an ignition interlock device, a temporary restricted license
 18  2 for a person convicted of a second or subsequent OWI may be
 18  3 conditioned on participation in the program. Upon the failure
 18  4 of a participant to submit to or pass a test under the program,
 18  5 the court may notify the department of transportation (DOT)
 18  6 of the person's noncompliance and direct the DOT to withdraw
 18  7 the person's temporary restricted license and reinstate the
 18  8 remainder of the license suspension period.
       LSB 6005HV (1) 86
